title: Citizenship Amendment Act protests
full_text: # Citizenship Amendment Act protests - [Article](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests) - [Talk](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests) | | | --- | | It has been suggested that _[2024 Citizenship Amendment Act protests](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests)_ be [merged](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Merging) into this article. ( [Discuss](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#Merger_discussion))_Proposed since April 2024._ | | | | --- | | This article **may be [too long](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Article_size) to read and navigate comfortably**. When this tag was added, its [readable prose size](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:SIZERULE) was 14,500 words. Consider [splitting](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Splitting) content into sub-articles, [condensing](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Summary_style) it, or adding [subheadings](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Section#Subsections). Please discuss this issue on the article's [talk page](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests)._(June 2024)_ | The **Citizenship Amendment Act (Bill) protests**, also known as the **CAA Protest**, **CAB Protest** or **CAA and NRC protests**,[\[74\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-74) occurred after the [Citizenship Amendment Act](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_(Amendment)_Act,_2019) (CAA) was enacted by the [Government of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_of_India) on 12 December 2019. The move sparked a widespread national and overseas ongoing protests against the act and its associated proposals of the [National Register of Citizens](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens) (NRC).[\[75\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-hansindia-75) The protests first began in [Assam](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam) and spread swiftly in other states such as[\[76\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-India_Today_12_Dec-76) Delhi,[\[77\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-77) [Meghalaya](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meghalaya),[\[78\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-78) [Arunachal Pradesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arunachal_Pradesh), and [Tripura](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tripura) on 4 December 2019.[\[45\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-mamata_rally-45) Protests broke out rapidly across the country, although the concerns of the protesters vary.[\[3\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-AtlanticLate-3)[\[79\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_Plea-79) protests | | (Counterclockwise from top) [Jamia Milia Islamia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Milia_Islamia) students protesting, protests in [Guwahati](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guwahati), Meghalaya, [Kerala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerala) and [Shaheen Bagh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaheen_Bagh_protests) (New Delhi), protesters stopping traffic, [Aisa](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_India_Students_Association) and [CPIML(L)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communist_Party_of_India_(Marxist-Leninist)_Liberation) protest in Kolkata. | | Date | 4 December 2019 (2019-12-04) – | | Location | [India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/India) | | Caused by | - Introduction of [Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_(Amendment)_Act,_2019) - Anticipation of implementation of the [National Register of Citizens of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens_of_India) - Police brutality against protesters[\[1\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-1)[\[2\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-2) - [Violent crackdown](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_repression) against protesters[\[3\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-AtlanticLate-3) | | Goals | - Repeal of the [Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_(Amendment)_Act,_2019) - Halt the implementation of the [National Register of Citizens of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens_of_India) - Independent Judicial probe into various [Police departments](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Police_departments) for [police brutality](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Police_brutality)[\[4\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-4)[\[5\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-5) - Resignation of [CM](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_Minister_of_Uttar_Pradesh) [Yogi Adityanath](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yogi_Adityanath)[\[6\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-6)[\[7\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-7)[\[8\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-8) - Release of various [political prisoners](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_prisoners)[\[9\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-9)[\[10\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-10)[\[11\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-11) | | Methods | **Protesters:** [Civil disobedience](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civil_disobedience), [demonstrations](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demonstration_(political)), _[Dharna](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dharna)_, _[Gherao](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gherao)_, [hunger strikes](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hunger_strikes), _[Satyagraha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satyagraha)_, _[Hartal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hartal)_, [vandalism](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vandalism), _[arson](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arson)_, [stone pelting](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stone_pelting), [hashtag activism](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hashtag_activism), [general strike](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_strike) _( [Bandh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bandh))_, Shooting **Government and supporters:** [Mass shooting](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_shooting) by police, [Riot police](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riot_police), [stone pelting](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stone_pelting), [vandalism](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vandalism), [_lathi charge_](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baton_charge), [Mass arrest](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_arrest), [Internet shutdown](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_shutdown), [curfew](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curfew), transport restrictions, [water cannon](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Water_cannon), imposing ban on assembly ( [Section 144](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Section_144)) | | Status | **Stopped**. It became indispensable to stop due to the [lockdown](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lockdown) being imposed in the country to curb the [COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_India)[\[12\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-12) **Previously:** - [Section 144](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Section_144), [curfew](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curfew), [Internet shutdown](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_shutdown) imposed in various parts of the country. - [Indian Army](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Army) deployed in [Assam](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam). - [Paramilitary forces](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paramilitary_forces_of_India) deployed in various parts of the country. | | Parties | | | | | | --- | --- | | [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Emblem_of_India.svg/40px-Emblem_of_India.svg.png)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Emblem_of_India.svg)**[Government of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_of_India)** - 3000+[\[73\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_17Dec-73) (reported as of 17 December) | The CAA amends the Indian citizenship act to provide accelerated pathway for citizenship for illegal migrants who are [Hindu](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindus), [Sikh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sikhs), [Jain](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jain), [Parsi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parsis), [Buddhist](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buddhist), and [Christian](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christians) from Afghanistan, Bangladesh and Pakistan, and who entered India before 2014, following the [religious persecutions](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Religious_persecution).[\[80\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_explained-80) The bill reduced the time taken for naturalization for this category from twelve years to six years. The bill does not mention [Muslims](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muslims) and other communities who fled from the same or other neighbouring countries. Refugees from [Sri Lankan Tamils in India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sri_Lankan_Tamils_in_India), [Rohingyas](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rohingya) from [Myanmar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myanmar), and [Tibetan refugees](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tibetan_refugees_in_India) are also not mentioned in the bill.[\[81\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IEConception-81)[\[82\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-82) The proposed [National Register of Citizens](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens) (NRC) will be an official record of all legal citizens of India. Individuals would need to provide a prescribed set of documents before a specified cutoff date to be included in it.[\[83\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-83) The amendment has been widely criticised as [discriminating on the basis of religion](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Religious_discrimination), particularity for excluding Muslims.[\[84\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NPRExcludes-84) Protestors against the amendment demand that it be scrapped and that the nationwide NRC not be implemented.[\[85\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-wsjdelhi-85)[\[86\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Sigal_Samuel-86)[\[87\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-87) The bill has raised concerns among the Indian Muslim community.[\[88\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-88)[\[89\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-89)[\[90\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-90)[\[91\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-91) They are also concerned that all citizens will be affected by the bureaucratic exercise of the NRC where they will have to prove their citizenship for inclusion in the registry.[\[92\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-92)[\[93\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-93) The protesters have raised voices against authoritarianism and the police crackdown in universities to suppress protests.[\[3\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-AtlanticLate-3)[\[94\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CaravanAuthoritarianism-94) Protesters in [Assam](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam) and other [northeastern states](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northeast_India) do not want [Indian citizenship](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_citizenship) to be granted to any refugee or immigrant, regardless of their religion, as they fear it would alter the region's demographic balance, resulting in a loss of their political rights, culture, and land.[\[95\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_2_Dead-95)[\[96\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-iexpressassam-96)[\[97\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-reuters1211-97) They are also concerned that it will motivate further [migration](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_migration) from [Bangladesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bangladesh) that could violate the [Assam Accord](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Accord) which was a prior agreement reached with the central government on migrants and refugees.[\[95\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_2_Dead-95)[\[96\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-iexpressassam-96)[\[97\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-reuters1211-97) The protests started in Assam on 4 December 2019, after the bill was introduced in parliament. Later on, protests erupted in [Northeast India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northeast_India), and subsequently spread to the major cities of India. On 15 December, major protests took place near [Jamia Millia Islamia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Millia_Islamia) in New Delhi and [Aligarh Muslim University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aligarh_Muslim_University). As the protests broke out, mobs burnt and destroyed public as well as private properties and several railway stations were vandalised.[\[98\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-98)[\[99\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-99)[\[100\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-100) Police [forcibly entered](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Jamia_Milia_Islamia_attack) the campus of Jamia, used batons and [tear gas](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tear_gas) on the students, and more than 200 students were injured while around 100 were detained overnight in the police station. The police action was widely criticised and resulted students across the country protesting in solidarity.[\[101\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-101)[\[102\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-102) The protests resulted in thousands of arrests and 27 deaths as of 27 December 2019.[\[103\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_arrests-103)[\[67\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-aljazeera_27_Dead-67) Two 17-year-old minors were among those reported to have been killed due to police firing during a live ammunition on protesters in Assam.[\[104\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-minors-104) On 19 December, the police issued a complete ban on protests in several parts of India. As a result of defying the ban, thousands of protesters were detained.[\[105\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-105) ## Contents - [1Background](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#Background) - [12See also](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#See_also) - [13References](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#References) - [14External links](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#External_links) ## Background [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=1) A child taking part in an anti-CAB NRC protest with [Jamia Millia Islamia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Millia_Islamia) students and locals. ### Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019 [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=2) Main article: [Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_(Amendment)_Act,_2019) [The Citizenship (Amendment) Bill, 2019](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Citizenship_(Amendment)_Bill,_2019) (CAB) was introduced by the Home Minister, [Amit Shah](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amit_Shah) on the floor of the Parliament of India on 9 December 2019 in response to the exclusion of 1.9 million people, predominantly Hindus and Muslims[\[106\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-106) in the [National Register of Citizens for Assam](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens_for_Assam).[\[107\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-107) The Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019 (CAA) was passed by the [Parliament of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parliament_of_India) on 11 December. It amends the [Citizenship Act of 1955](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_nationality_law) to grant a swifter path to Indian citizenship under the assumption of [religious persecution](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Religious_persecution) to any individual belonging to the specific minorities of [Hindus](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindus), [Sikhs](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sikhs), [Buddhists](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buddhist), [Jains](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jain), [Parsis](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parsis) and Christians from [Afghanistan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Afghanistan), [Bangladesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bangladesh) and [Pakistan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pakistan), who entered India on or before 31 December 2014.[\[108\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-108) The Act also seeks to relax the requirement of residence in India for citizenship by [naturalisation](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naturalisation) from 11 years to 5 years for migrants covered under the Act.[\[109\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-109) However, the Act does not mention Muslims and does not offer the same eligibility benefits to Muslim immigrants or immigrants belonging to other religions from those countries.[\[110\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Samuel-110) The Act also does not mention any benefits for various other refugees which form the bulk of the refugees living in India, such as [Sri Lankan Tamil refugees](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sri_Lankan_Tamils_in_India) who faced persecution during the [Sri Lankan Civil War](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sri_Lankan_Civil_War),[\[111\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-111) [Rohingya refugees](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rohingya_Refugee_Crisis) who were victims of the [Rohingya genocide](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rohingya_genocide), [Nepali refugees](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhutanese_refugees) who faced [ethnic cleansing in Bhutan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnic_cleansing_in_Bhutan), and [Tibetan Buddhist refugees](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tibetan_refugees_in_India) who faced persecution in China.[\[112\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-WPCitizenship22-112) According to the [Intelligence Bureau](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligence_Bureau_(India)), the immediate beneficiaries of the new law will be 25,447 Hindus, 5,807 Sikhs, 55 Christians, 2 Buddhists and 2 Parsis.[\[113\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-angry22-113) ### Response [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=3) The passage of the Act sparked massive protests in India.[\[110\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Samuel-110) Protesters in [Assam](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam) and other [northeastern states](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northeast_India) oppose the grant of [Indian citizenship](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_citizenship) to any refugee or immigrant, regardless of their religion, because they fear it would alter the region's demographic balance. They have campaigned since the 1970s against all refugees, and they fear that the new law will cause a loss of their political rights, culture and land.[\[95\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_2_Dead-95)[\[96\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-iexpressassam-96)[\[97\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-reuters1211-97) They are also concerned that it will trigger more migration from [Bangladesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bangladesh) as well as violate the [Assam Accord](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Accord), which was a prior agreement reached with the central government on migrants and refugees.[\[95\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_2_Dead-95)[\[96\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-iexpressassam-96)[\[97\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-reuters1211-97) After the act was passed, protests in the northeastern region turned violent. Authorities had arrested over 3000 protesters as of 17 December 2019,[\[73\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_17Dec-73) and some news outlets have described these protests as [riots](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riots).[\[114\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-114) Protesters say that the Act violates Clause 5 and Clause 6 of the 1985 [Assam Accord](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Accord).[\[115\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-115) Critics have stated that the amendment Act is unconstitutional.[\[116\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-116)[\[117\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-guardian-117)[\[118\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-118) The major opposition political parties state that it violates Constitution's Article 14, one that guarantees equality to all. They allege that the new law seeks to make Muslims second-class citizens of India, while preferentially treating non-Muslims in India.[\[119\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-119) Critics of the Act have also stated that due to the [National Register of Citizens (NRC)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens_of_India), Muslims could be made [stateless](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statelessness), while the Citizenship Amendment Act would be able to shield people with Hindu, Sikh, Buddhist, Jain, Parsi or Christian identity as a means of providing them with Indian citizenship even if they fail to prove that they were citizens of India under the stringent requirements of the NRC. Some critics allege that it is a deliberate attempt at [disenfranchising](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disfranchisement) and segregating Muslims in line with the [ethnonationalist](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnonationalist) [Hindutva](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindutva) ideology of the ruling [Bharatiya Janata Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party) (BJP).[\[120\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-120)[\[81\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IEConception-81)[\[121\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-AsianAgeOrwellian-121) [Tavleen Singh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tavleen_Singh) described the Act as India's first [Nuremberg Law](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuremberg_Laws).[\[122\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-122) The home minister [Amit Shah](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amit_Shah) had previously set a deadline for the implementation of a countrywide NRC by stating that the register would be rolled out before the [2024 Lok Sabha elections](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Indian_general_election).[\[123\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-livemint_NRC-123) The Act was criticised by various NGOs, students bodies, and liberal, progressive, and socialist organisations across the country, with the [Indian National Congress](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_National_Congress) and other major political parties announcing their staunch opposition. Protests led by these groups are concerned that the new law discriminates against Muslims, and believe that Indian citizenship should also be granted to Muslim refugees and immigrants. The states of [Rajasthan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rajasthan), West Bengal, [Kerala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerala), Maharashtra, [Madhya Pradesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madhya_Pradesh), Jharkhand[\[124\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-124) and [Chhattisgarh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chhattisgarh) – all ruled by political parties that oppose the BJP – have announced that they will not implement either the [National Register of Citizens](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens) (NRC) or the Citizenship Amendment Act. The states of [Bihar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bihar), Andhra Pradesh and [Odisha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Odisha) have however refused to only implement the NRC, while the state of [Punjab](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punjab,_India) and the union territories of Delhi and [Puducherry](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Puducherry_(union_territory)) have refused to implement the Act while only expressing disapproval of the NRC.[\[125\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-125)[\[126\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-126)[\[127\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-127) The states of [West Bengal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Bengal) and [Kerala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerala) have also put a hold on all activities relating to the preparation and update of the [National Population Register](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Population_Register) which is necessary for the Census as well as the implementation of the [National Register of Citizens](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens).[\[128\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-128) Although some of the states have opposed the Act, the [Union Home Ministry](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ministry_of_Home_Affairs_(India)) clarified that states lack the legal power to stop the implementation of CAA. The Ministry stated that "The new legislation has been enacted under the Union List of the 7th Schedule of the Constitution. The states have no power to reject it."[\[129\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Outlook_MP_19_Dec-129) The [Indian Union Muslim League](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Union_Muslim_League) and various other bodies have also petitioned the [Supreme Court of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_India) to strike down the Act as illegal and unconstitutional.[\[130\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-bbc-130) ## Chronology [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=4) ### December 2019 [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=5) - **4 December** - The Citizenship (Amendment) Bill, 2019 was cleared by the [Union Cabinet](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Union_Council_of_Ministers) for introduction in the parliament.[\[131\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-131) - After the bill was cleared, violent protests erupted in Assam, especially in [Guwahati](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guwahati), and other areas in the state.[\[132\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ET_CAA_12-132) - In [Dispur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dispur), several thousands of protesters broke down police barricades to protest in front of the [Assam Legislative Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Legislative_Assembly) building.[\[133\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-133)[\[134\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-New_York_Times-134) - Demonstrations were held in [Agartala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agartala).[\[135\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-135) Six people died and fifty people were injured in the protests against the Act.[\[136\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-136)[\[137\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_16_Dec-137) - **9 December** - The bill was introduced in the [Lok Sabha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lok_Sabha) by the Minister of Home Affairs, [Amit Shah](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amit_Shah).[\[138\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-138) - **10 December** - The bill was passed with 311 members voting in favour and 80 against.[\[139\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-139)[\[140\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-140) - **11 December** - The bill was subsequently passed by the [Rajya Sabha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rajya_Sabha) with 125 votes in favour and 105 votes against it. Those parties that had voted in favour include BJP allies such as the [Janata Dal (United)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Janata_Dal_(United)) and the [AIADMK](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_India_Anna_Dravida_Munnetra_Kazhagam) and non-aligned parties such as the [Biju Janata Dal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biju_Janata_Dal).[\[141\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_RS_Passed-141) - **12 December** - After receiving assent from the [President of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_India), the bill assumed the status of an act.[\[142\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-assent-142) The act would come into force on 10 January, chosen by the Government of India, and would be notified as such.[\[143\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-gazette-143)[\[144\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CAA_in_force_10_Jan-144) - Dipanjal Das and Sam Stafford were killed in police firing during a protest in Guwahati.[\[145\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto3-145) - [Akhil Gogoi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Akhil_Gogoi) was taken in preventive custody.[\[146\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ITAkhil19-146) A poster at Shaheen Bagh protests New Delhi - **13 December** - UK, US, France, Israel and Canada issued [travel warnings](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travel_warning) for their citizens visiting India's north-east region, where the protests were mainly taking place, asking them to "exercise caution".[\[147\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-147) - The Chief Ministers of the Indian states of West Bengal, Punjab, Kerala, Madhya Pradesh and Chhattisgarh had stated that they would not implement the act.[\[148\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-148) - **14 December** - Ishwar Nayak was killed in police firing at a protest in Assam.[\[149\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-quint_CAA-149) - Thousands of people protested against the law at the [Jantar Mantar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jantar_Mantar,_New_Delhi) in New Delhi.[\[150\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Telegraph_Jantar-150)[\[151\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Jantar-151) - **15 December** - In Assam, Abdul Alim, a protester, died due to police firing in a protest the previous day.[\[149\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-quint_CAA-149)[\[152\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-152) - In Jamia Nagar, Delhi, three [Delhi Transport Corporation](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_Transport_Corporation) buses were torched as protests took a violent turn.[\[153\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-:5-153) - A group of artists in [Guwahati](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guwahati,_Assam) staged a concert in protest against the Citizenship Amendment Act 2019.[\[154\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-154) - Police forcefully entered the campus of [Jamia Milia Islamia university](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Millia_Islamia) and detained students. According to video footage, the police used batons and tear gas on the students. More than two hundred students were injured and around a hundred were detained. The police action was widely criticised, and resulted in protests across the country and abroad.[\[155\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Reuters16Dec-155) There were also allegations that the police attacked students who were not part of the protests.[\[156\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-156) - Protests were held outside the campus of the [Aligarh Muslim University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aligarh_Muslim_University). In the evening, police officers forcefully entered the campus and attacked students. At least 80 students were injured in the attacks.[\[157\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Aligarh-157)[\[158\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-158) - In West Bengal, violent protests occurred and five trains were set on fire by protesters in [Lalgola](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lalgola_railway_station) and [Krishnapur railway stations](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Krishnapur_railway_station) in [Murshidabad district](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Murshidabad_district).[\[159\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_14Dec-159) - **16 December** - In Lucknow, police prevented around 300 students of [Nadwa University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nadwa_University) from staging a peaceful protest outside the campus; clashes ensued later.[\[160\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-HT_Nadwa-160) Around 15 to 20 students were injured and around 30 students were charged by the police for attempt to murder and violence.[\[161\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Exp_Nadwa_17_Dec-161) - [Priyanka Gandhi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Priyanka_Gandhi) led a silent protest at the [India Gate](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/India_Gate) along with about three hundred [Indian National Congress](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_National_Congress) workers to show solidarity with the students of Jamia Milia Islamia after the previous day's incidents.[\[49\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Priyanka_Gandhi-49) - A [Satyagraha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satyagraha) was organised by the [All Assam Students' Union](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_Assam_Students%27_Union) across [Assam](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam), which would continue till 18 December.[\[162\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ITAASU-162) - In West Bengal thousands of people joined a demonstration led by Chief Minister [Mamata Banerjee](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mamata_Banerjee) and her ruling [Trinamool Congress](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_India_Trinamool_Congress) party.[\[79\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_Plea-79) - Prime Minister [Narendra Modi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Narendra_Modi) appealed for calm on Twitter and clarified that CAA was for immigrants.[\[137\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_16_Dec-137)[\[163\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-163)\[ _[non-primary source needed](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research#Primary,_secondary_and_tertiary_sources)_\] - **17 December** - Violent clashes occurred in Delhi's [Seelampur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seelampur_subdivision) area. Police retaliated with tear gas and batons against the stone throwing protesters. Several protesters and officers were injured. A police station was set on fire and buses were vandalised in the area.[\[164\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-bbc_Seelampur-164) - A dawn-to-dusk hartal (shutdown) was observed in Kerala by the [Welfare Party of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Welfare_Party_of_India), [Bahujan Samaj Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bahujan_Samaj_Party), [Social Democratic Party of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_of_India) and 30 other organisations against the Citizenship Amendment Act and the police violence against students at various universities across the country, in relation to anti-CAA protests.[\[165\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ITStoned-165)[\[166\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TimesNowKeralaHartal-166) - **18 December** - The [Supreme Court of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_India) heard 60 petitions challenging the Act and declined to stay implementation of CAA. 22 January 2020 was set as the next date of hearing on the constitutional validity of the act.[\[167\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-167) - A statement "condemning the recent police action and brutalisation of students at Jamia Millia University and Aligarh Muslim University" was signed by signatories from more than 1,100 academic institutions across the world.[\[94\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CaravanAuthoritarianism-94) - **19 December** - 3 protesters (2 in [Mangalore](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mangalore) and 1 in [Lucknow](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucknow)) were killed in police firing.[\[168\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_3_lives-168) - Various administrative authorities imposed bans against public gatherings, especially in [BJP](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party) ruled states such as [Karnataka](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karnataka), Uttar Pradesh and parts of Delhi, where the police comes under the BJP-ruled central government.[\[169\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Shah_Meeting-169)[\[170\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Live_19-170) Access to [mobile-based internet](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_broadband) was shut down in certain places in Delhi and Bangalore.[\[169\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Shah_Meeting-169) - Internet was suspended in certain regions of Uttar Pradesh including the state capital, [Lucknow](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucknow) where data and text services were restricted till noon of 21 December 2019. Internet services were also suspended in Sambhal, Aligarh, Mau, Ghaziabad, and Azamgarh districts, as well as [Dakshina Kannada](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dakshina_Kannada) district in Karnataka.[\[171\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-171) - Protest meetings were held defying bans in Delhi's [Red Fort](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_Fort) and Bengaluru.[\[169\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Shah_Meeting-169) Tens of thousands of people protested in Hyderabad, Patna, Chandigarh, Mumbai and other cities. Calls were made on social media platforms asking people to turn up and protest peacefully.[\[172\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_19_Dec-172) - In Delhi, politicians [Yogendra Yadav](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yogendra_Yadav) and [Sitaram Yechury](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sitaram_Yechury) along with around 1,200 protesters were detained by the police.[\[169\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Shah_Meeting-169)[\[173\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-173) - In Delhi, at least 700 flights were delayed and more than 20 cancelled due to traffic jams caused by police closing roads to stop protests.[\[174\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Flights-174) - In Bengaluru, historian [Ramchandra Guha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramchandra_Guha) along with several other professors were detained by the police. According to the police, around 200 protesters had been detained in Bengaluru.[\[169\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Shah_Meeting-169) - Curfew was imposed in [Mangaluru](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mangaluru) until 20 December, after violent clashes and the death of 2 people due to police firing.[\[170\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Live_19-170)[\[175\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ToIMalayali19-175) The police later allegedly forced its way into the hospital where the 2 victims were brought.[\[176\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto2-176)[\[177\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto1-177) - UNICEF issued a statement asking the government to respect children's right of freedom of expression, peaceful assembly and protest as per the [Convention on the Rights of the Child](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convention_on_the_Rights_of_the_Child).[\[170\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Live_19-170) - In [Ahmedabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ahmedabad), during a violent clash in the [Shah-e-Alam's Roza](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shah-e-Alam%27s_Roza) area police used tear gas to defend themselves and counter [stone pelting](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stone_pelting) while trying to disperse a crowd of around 2000 protesters.[\[178\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_Gujarat_19-178) - 90 protesters including 50 students of the [Hyderabad university](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyderabad_university) were detained by [Hyderabad police](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyderabad_police).[\[170\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Live_19-170) - A crowd consisting of thousands of protesters gathered at [Moulali](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moulali) in central [Kolkata](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kolkata) to peacefully protest against CAA and NRC.[\[170\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Live_19-170) - Protests involving 20,000 protesters concluded peacefully at the [August Kranti Maidan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/August_Kranti_Maidan) at Mumbai.[\[179\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Mumbai_Mirror_19-179) - **20 December** - 6 protesters (one each in [Meerut](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meerut), [Sambhal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sambhal), [Kanpur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kanpur) and [Firozabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Firozabad) and 2 in [Bijnor](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bijnor)) were killed in separate police firing incidents in UP.[\[180\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-news18_6_deaths_in_up-180) - [Bhim Army](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhim_Army) Chief [Chandrashekhar Azad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chandrashekhar_Azad_Ravan) conducted a protest march at the [Jama Masjid](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jama_Masjid,_Delhi) in Delhi.[\[181\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Bhim-181) - **21 December** - Chandrashekhar Azad was arrested along with 27 people and three FIRs were registered for certain violent incidents on 20 December at [Delhi Gate](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_Gate,_Delhi) and Seemapuri.[\[182\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_16_Killed-182) - 1100 academics and academia staff from around the world issued a joint statement supporting the act.[\[183\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-183) - Peaceful protests were conducted in West Bengal, Assam, Meghalaya, Maharashtra and Delhi.[\[182\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_16_Killed-182) An all-woman protest was organised across Assam.[\[184\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ReutersHundreds-184) - A spontaneous protest march, approximately 1.5 km long occurred in Kolkata.[\[185\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TelegraphFloodgates-185) - Clashes were reported during protests near [Chennai Central railway station](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chennai_Central_railway_station).[\[182\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_16_Killed-182) - 1 protester dies and several are injured in clashes at multiple locations in Uttar Pradesh. Access to the internet is still restricted at many places.[\[182\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_16_Killed-182) - In Patna and other towns of Bihar, supporters of the [Rashtriya Janata Dal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rashtriya_Janata_Dal) (RJD) protested at bus and train stations and blocked roads.[\[182\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_16_Killed-182) - An 18-year-old protester, Amir Hanzla was beaten to death by [Hindu extremists](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saffron_terror) for his role in the protests.[\[186\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-186)[\[187\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-187) - **22 December** - The [Chief Minister of Rajasthan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_Minister_of_Rajasthan), [Ashok Gehlot](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ashok_Gehlot) held a protest march termed the " [Samvidhan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constitution_of_India) Bachao Rally" which was attended by around 300,000 people.[\[188\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ITRajasthan-188) - The Karnataka government announced an ex-gratia compensation of [₹](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_rupee)10 [lakh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lakh) (US$12,000) each to the families of the two men killed in violent protests against the Citizenship Amendment Act in Mangaluru on 19 December.[\[189\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-News18_Kar_10_Lakh-189) However, the compensation was withheld on 26 December, impending an enquiry on the killed men.[\[190\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IE_26_Dec_Karnataka-190) - The Uttar Pradesh government created a panel to assess the damage to the property and to recover the losses by seizing the property of the alleged protesters.[\[191\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Lucknow_22_Dec_IT-191) - **23 December** - Protests involving 80,000 protesters concluded peacefully in Bangalore.[\[192\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ToI_80000-192) - Dibrugarh police arrested 55 people for involvement in acts of violence in the district during protests against the Amendment.[\[193\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-193) - Unidentified people assaulted three migrant labourers from West Bengal for allegedly taking part in anti-CAA protests.[\[194\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-194) - An FIR was registered against [AAP](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aam_Aadmi_Party) MLA [Amanatullah Khan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amanatullah_Khan) over charges of "sharing an objectionable post" on the social media against the act.[\[195\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-195) - 31 people were arrested for violence during an anti-CAA protest in [Rampur, Uttar Pradesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rampur,_Uttar_Pradesh).[\[196\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-196) - **24 December** - Despite widespread ongoing protests, the central government approved the updation of the [National Population Register](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Population_Register) (NPR) and allocated [₹](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_rupee)3,941.35 [crore](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crore) (US$470 million) for it.[\[197\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-News18_24_dec-197) - A German exchange student at [IIT Madras](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/IIT_Madras) was deported by the Indian authorities for participating in the CAA protests.[\[198\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-AP_German-198)[\[199\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-German_Express-199) - Reports of [police](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh_Police) vandalising homes, shops and cars and accusing and arresting protesters of taking part in vandalism emerged from various parts of the state of [Uttar Pradesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh).[\[200\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-News18Muzaffarnagar-200)[\[201\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-SiasatRakshak-201)[\[202\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTVVandalising-202) - 1,000-1,200 protesters were booked for organising a candle march in [Aligarh Muslim University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aligarh_Muslim_University) for violating Section 144.[\[203\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto7-203) - **26 December** - In [Sambhal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sambhal), UP, the government sent notices to 26 people for their alleged involvement in damaging properties during protests and asked them to explain their position or pay for the loss due to damage of property. The losses to the property were assessed to be [₹](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_rupee)11.66 [lakh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lakh) (US$14,000).[\[204\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Sambhal_Damage-204) - **27 December** - 357 people including 75 women protesting against CAA and police atrocities were detained by the Delhi police near the UP Bhavan.[\[205\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TH_28_Dec_UP-205) - **28 December** - The [Indian National Congress](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_National_Congress), on its foundation day, undertook a flag march in Mumbai and coined the slogan "Save Bharat-Save Constitution".[\[206\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CAA_Express_live_28_Dec-206) Similar marches were held in many parts of the country.[\[207\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Congress_28_Dec_N18-207) - In [Meerut](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meerut), U.P. government demanded ₹25,000 (US$300) each from more than 140 people, a total of [₹](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_rupee)40 [lakh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lakh) (US$48,000) as penalty for damages caused during protests on 20 December.[\[208\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Express_28_Dec_UP-208) - **29 December** - The [Shaheen Bagh protests](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaheen_Bagh_protests), which started on 15 December and were participated in mainly by house wives and old women with their children,[\[209\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-209)[\[210\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-210)[\[211\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-211) gathered mainstream media attention on 29 December. Despite Delhi experiencing the second coldest night in the last 100 years,[\[212\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-212)[\[213\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-213) the women protesters sat on an indefinite protest at Shaheen Bagh, .[\[214\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-214)[\[215\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-215)[\[216\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-216) [Shaheen Bagh protests](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaheen_Bagh_protests) on 4 January 2020. Protesters are still gathered blocking a major New Delhi road for over three weeks.[\[217\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-217) (Bottom) Huge anti-CAA NRC banners across a footbridge at Shaheen Bagh. - LGBT Rights activists protested against the CAA and NRC at the [Kolkata Pride Parade](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kolkata_Rainbow_Pride_Walk).[\[218\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-218)[\[219\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-219) - **30 December** - Delhi Police arrested street vendors, accusing them of stone pelting and inciting violence during the Jamia Milia Islamia attacks.[\[220\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-220)[\[221\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-221) - **31 December** - Protests were held during New Year's Eve celebrations in Delhi,[\[222\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-222) Hyderabad,[\[223\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-223) [Bhubaneshwar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhubaneshwar),[\[224\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-224) Mumbai and Kolkata.[\[225\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-225)[\[226\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-226) ### January 2020 [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=6) - **1 January** - About 50,000–170,000[\[227\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-227) people participated in an anti-CAA rally organised by Muslim organisations[\[228\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-228) in [Kochi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kochi).[\[229\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-229)[\[230\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-230) The numbers swelled to 500,000,[\[231\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-231) the unusually large size of the protest causing a complete standstill of traffic throughout the city.[\[232\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-232) - **3 January** - The UP Police admitted that it had wrongfully accused and arrested poor innocent people; and releases four minors from jail due to lack of evidence.[\[233\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-233)[\[234\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-234) - **4 January** - More than 100,000 protesters attended a protest march named "Million March" against the Citizenship Amendment Bill held in Hyderabad.[\[235\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Reuters_4_Jan_Hyd-235) - In Bangalore hundreds of protesters participated in a rally and accused the [Modi government](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modi_government) of attempting to divide India on the basis of religion, and distracting people from the issues of economic slowdown and unemployment in the country.[\[235\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Reuters_4_Jan_Hyd-235) - **5 January** - A masked mob, allegedly composed of [Hindu extremists](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saffron_terror) from the [Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Akhil_Bharatiya_Vidyarthi_Parishad), armed with rods and sticks attacked the campus of [Jawaharlal Nehru University, Delhi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru_University,_Delhi) and injured more than 40 students and teachers.[\[236\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Masked_JNU-236) The attack was described as an attempt to suppress [student activism](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Student_activism) during the Citizenship Amendment Act protests.[\[237\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-237) - **6 January** - 50,000 women held an "all women's rally" in [Malegaon](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malegaon), Maharashtra.[\[238\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-:2-238) - **7 January** - Women in Kolkata started a sit-in protest at the grounds of Park Circus in Kolkata.[\[239\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Park_Circus_16_Jan-239) - **8 January** - PM Modi cancelled his visit to Assam, while the CAA protests continue. AASU had planned huge protests during Modi's visit.[\[240\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TNIE_Modi_8_Jan-240)[\[241\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Outlook_8_Jan-241) - Thousands of people joined the anti-CAA protests at Dibrugarh, Guwahati and other parts of Assam.[\[242\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Telegraph_8_January-242)[\[243\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-nenow_8_January_2020-243) - **9 January** - Students of JNU attempted to march towards [Rashtrapati Bhavan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rashtrapati_Bhavan), the official residence of the [President of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_India) while blocking [Janpath](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Janpath). Police detained around 100 students when the march was blocking Janpath.[\[244\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-244) - The Chief Justice of India dismissed a petition by a lawyer demanding that the CAA be declared constitutionally valid, stating that "There is anyway a presumption of constitutionality".[\[245\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-245) - Asom Jatiyatabadi Yuba Chatra Parishad (AJYCP) along with All Assam Students’ Union (AASU), the Krishak Mukti Sangram Samiti (KMSS) and 30 other organisations and artist communities organised protests against CAA in [Guwahati](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guwahati). They demanded "corruption-free, foreigner-free, terrorism-free and pollution-free Assam" from the Chief Minister of Assam, [Sarbananda Sonowal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarbananda_Sonowal) rather than implementing CAA-NRC.[\[242\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Telegraph_8_January-242) - **10 January** - The Citizenship Amendment Act came into force.[\[144\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CAA_in_force_10_Jan-144) - The [Delhi High Court](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_High_Court) dismissed a plea to remove the [protesters occupying Shaheen Bagh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaheen_Bagh_protests).[\[246\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Delhi_HC_10_Jan-246) - **11 January** - PM Modi visited Kolkata on a two day official visit. Hundreds of people protested against CAA at the Kolkata airport.[\[247\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Rediff_11_Jan-247) - Several parties and student unions launched a protest at the Dorina Crossing at Esplanade in Kolkata. SFI leader stated that the protests would continue till Sunday, until PM Modi (who had been visiting the city) was in Kolkata.[\[248\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-News18_11_Jan-248) - A " [Tiranga](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flag_of_India) Rally" against the CAA was held in Hyderabad, with thousands[\[249\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-249) of people displaying the national flag.[\[250\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-250) Police officers were seen [caning](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caning) peaceful protesters.[\[251\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-251) - [Pradyot Manikya Debbarma](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kirit_Pradyot_Deb_Barman), the royal scion of the [Manikya dynasty](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manikya_dynasty), led the largest protest in Tripura as of 11 January 2020 consisting of thousands of people.[\[252\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_12_Jan-252) Debbarma stated that beneficiaries of CAA will not be allowed to settle in Tripura. He added that the state has already accommodated many migrants from [East Pakistan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Pakistan) and further immigration due to CAA will endanger the threatened indigenous residents of Tripura.[\[252\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_12_Jan-252) - **12 January** - In Kolkata, the protesters outside the venue of PM Modi's speech were detained by the police.[\[253\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Ramakrishna_12_Jan-253) - Thousands of people join the anti CAA protests at Jogeshwari in Mumbai. Slogans such as "I Am From Gujarat, My Documents Burned in 2002", "No CAA, Boycott NRC, Stop Dividing India, Don't Divide us", "Save Constitution", were displayed on the banners.[\[254\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CAA_live_13_Jan-254) - The Indian National Congress demanded the withdrawal of CAA, and stopping of the process to update NPR. It claimed that the NPR was a 'disguised NRC'.[\[254\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CAA_live_13_Jan-254) - **13 January** - The [Parliamentary panel on Home Affairs](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Indian_parliamentary_committees#Department-related_standing_committees) criticised the Delhi Police for the violent crackdown on Jamia and JNU and asked them not to be harsh.[\[255\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_CAA_13_Jan-255) - A meeting of 20 opposition parties in Delhi released a statement demanding a revocation of the CAA and asked all the Chief Ministers who have refused to implement the NRC in their states to stop the work of updating the [National Population Register](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Population_Register), as it is the foundation of NRC.[\[256\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Stop_NPR_13_Jan-256)[\[254\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CAA_live_13_Jan-254) - At Jamia Millia Islamia, several student groups protested outside the office of Vice-Chancellor Najma Akhtar asking to reschedule the exam dates, filing a case against Delhi Police and ensuring the safety of students. The VC announced in the afternoon, that a case will be filed against police on 14 January.[\[254\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CAA_live_13_Jan-254) - **14 January** - The [Kerala government](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerala_government) approached the Supreme Court to challenge the CAA under Section 131 of the Constitution and became the first state to do so.[\[257\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Kerala_CAA_14_Jan-257)[\[258\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-14_Jan-258) - [Mani Shankar Aiyar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mani_Shankar_Aiyar) of the Indian National Congress joined the anti CAA protesters at Shaheen Bagh.[\[259\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CAA_Live14_Jan-259) - 5000 women staged a sit-in protest at Mansoor Ali park in [Prayagraj](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prayagraj), Uttar Pradesh.[\[260\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Live_14_Jan-260) - In Mumbai, a group of students attended the India v/s Australia match at Wankhede stadium and peacefully protested by wearing T-shirts with the message "No NPR, NO NRC and NO CAA".[\[260\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Live_14_Jan-260) - In Gujarat, people celebrated [Makar Sankranti](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Makar_Sankranti) by flying kites with slogans for and against CAA.[\[261\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-261) - **15 January** - More than 200,000 people joined the Anti-CAA protests in Mangalore, where hundreds of people came in boats carrying Indian flags. Activists Harsh Mander and former [IAS officer](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/IAS_officer) Kannan Gopinathan gave speeches during the protests. The protests ended peacefully with the singing of National anthem.[\[262\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Mangalore_15_Jan-262) - Women conducted sit-in protests at Patna's [Sabzibagh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Sabzibagh&action=edit&redlink=1) and Kolkata's [Park Circus](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Park_Circus), Allahabad's Roshan Bagh, Kanpur's [Chaman Ganj](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chaman_Ganj,_Kanpur), Gaya's Shanti Bagh along with Delhi's Shaheen Bagh.[\[263\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Wire_Guj_15_Jan-263)[\[264\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-264) - A petition was filed in Gujarat High court asking its intervention to allow citizens to hold Anti-CAA protests in Ahmedabad. The petitioners stated that the Gujarat Police did not grant them permission for peaceful protests but granted permission to 62 programmes held by the ruling BJP to support the CAA. The court asked the police to decide properly on the protesters' applications.[\[263\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Wire_Guj_15_Jan-263) - A Delhi court granted bail and released Bhim Army chief Chandrashekhar Azad aka "Raavan", who had been arrested for his protest in December against CAA at [Jama Masjid, Delhi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jama_Masjid,_Delhi).[\[265\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Azad_bail_15_Jan-265) - Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) postpones all exams due to the ongoing CAA protests.[\[266\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-AMU_postpones_exams_15_Jan-266) - **16 January** - Police in [Chennai](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chennai) banned all protests in the city for a period of 15 days. Five women and one man (including a physically disabled person) were detained by the police for protesting against CAA.[\[267\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TNM_Chennai_16_Jan-267) - **17 January** - Inspired by the Shaheen Bagh protest, a massive anti-CAA-NRC-NPR protest was started in Mumbai. Around 10,000 women gathered at the YMCA ground in Mumbai to protest in the evening. The protest was organised by a Non-governmental organisation named Mumbai Citizen Quorum.[\[268\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Shaheen_Mumbai-268)[\[269\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-269) - Around 500 women began a sit-in protest at the Clock tower grounds in Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh.[\[270\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TH_19_Jan_blanket-270) - **18 January** - Uttar Pradesh police cracked down on the CAA protesters demonstrating near the Clock Tower in [Lucknow](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucknow) and snatched their personal belongings.[\[271\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-UP_blanket_19_Jan-271) - **19 January** - In Delhi, hundreds of protesters joined a protest march holding lighted candles from Jamia University to Shaheen Bagh.[\[272\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-19_Jan_Delhi_candle-272) - In [Berlin](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin), Germany more than 200 people join the protest march against CAA, NRC and the [JNU attack](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_JNU_attack). The march was led by the Indian diaspora and started at the [Brandenburg Gate](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brandenburg_Gate) and ended at the Indian Embassy.[\[273\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Germany_19_Jan-273) - An all women protest started on 11 January, outside Konark Mall in [Pune](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pune), organised by Kul Jamaat-e-Tanzeem, an umbrella body of several organisations, reached its ninth day with around 500–600 protesters participating all throughout the day.[\[274\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-19_Jan_Pune_Shaheen-274) - **20 January** - Several [Labour Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK)) [MPs](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Member_of_parliament) of the [Uk parliament](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uk_parliament) discussed concerns regarding the CAA, in a meeting organised by South Asia Solidarity Group (SASG) and Ambedkar International Mission (UK) in London.[\[275\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Labour_MP_21_Jan-275) The MPs expressed concern on its implications on human rights and disenfranchisement of the Muslim community.[\[276\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-newsclick_labour_UK-276) - **21 January** - More than 300,000 people join an anti-CAA protest rally at [Kalaburagi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kalaburagi) in Karnataka.[\[277\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Kalburgi_22_Jan-277) - In UP's Etawah, a video emerged that showed Police chasing and attacking the women protesters with batons in their attempts to break the protest.[\[278\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-22_Jan_Etawah_stick-278) - In a unique way of protesting, more than a hundred women protesters at Khureji Khas in Delhi released 10,000 gas filled black coloured balloons with the message "No CAA NPR NRC".[\[279\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-10K_quint-279)[\[280\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-10000_balloons-280) - Police register cases against 160 women for violation of the ban on assembly and protesting against CAA in Lucknow.[\[281\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-160_booked_21_Jan-281) - Despite ban on assembly, Home Minister Amit Shah was allowed by the administration to address a pro CAA public rally at Lucknow.[\[281\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-160_booked_21_Jan-281) Amit Shah said that the protesters could continue protesting but the government would not revoke the CAA.[\[282\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Amit_Shah_Lucknow_21_Jan-282) - Various college students' associations had called a complete shutdown of colleges and universities in the north-east on 22 Jan, asking the Supreme Court to declare CAA as unconstitutional.[\[283\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_NE_strike_21_Jan-283) - **22 January** - Thousands of students from 9 universities in North-East India boycott classes and join protest march in the states of [Assam](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam), Nagaland, [Meghalaya](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meghalaya) and [Arunachal Pradesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arunachal_Pradesh).[\[284\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-HT_22_Jan_Assam-284)[\[285\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Assam_CAA_22_Jan-285)[\[286\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-22_Jan_NDTV_NE-286) - A 5 kilometre long procession against CAA was led by CM [Mamata Banerjee](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mamata_Banerjee) in [Darjeeling](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Darjeeling), West Bengal.[\[287\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-22_Jan_Darjeeling-287) - Women continued sit-in protests for the third day at the Haj House near Kadru Over Bridge in [Ranchi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ranchi), Jharkhand.[\[288\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Ranchi_23_Jan-288) - 144 CAA related petitions scheduled for hearing in the Supreme Court of India were brought up. [Chief Justice of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_India) [Sharad A. Bobde](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sharad_A._Bobde) had led the three-judge bench.[\[289\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-144_petitions_21_Jan-289) The court gave notice to the government on the petitions and allowed one month to respond in the next hearing in February.[\[290\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-SC_refuses_22_Jan-290) The Supreme Court also segregated the case of Assam and Tripura considering the fact of cross-border infiltration and assured of looking into the matter separately.[\[291\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-291) - A fact-finding team consisting of students of various prominent universities like [Banaras Hindu University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Banaras_Hindu_University), [Jamia Millia Islamia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Millia_Islamia) and [JNU](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru_University) released a report after visiting 15 violence-affected cities in Uttar Pradesh and accused the Uttar Pradesh police of brutality in dealing with protesters and attacking Muslims. The police was accused of violating basic principles of fire arms usage by firing above the waist.[\[292\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-23_Jan_Student_fact-292) - While addressing a Pro-CAA public meeting in Lucknow the CM of UP threatened to charge the protesters with [sedition](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sedition) if they raised slogans demanding _Azadi_ (Freedom) in Uttar Pradesh.[\[293\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Azadi_slogan_UP_22_Jan-293) - **24 January** - A statewide shutdown, "Maharashtra Bandh" was organised by Vanchit Bahujan Aghadi (VBA) across [Maharashtra](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maharashtra) state, to protest against the CAA and the economic policies of the BJP-led central government, which according to the organisers "were ruining the country".[\[294\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-N18_24_January_2020-294)[\[295\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-HT_24_Jan_Maha_Bandh-295) - Curfew was imposed in Jharkhand's [Lohardaga district](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lohardaga_district) after a clash and violence between pro and anti CAA protesters.[\[296\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-24_Jan_Lohardaga-296) -
