**25 January** - In London, around 2000 people from the Indian diaspora and the Human Rights organisation conducted a protest march against CAA from the Downing Street to the [Indian High Commission](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/India_House,_London).[\[297\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-26_Jan_2K_London-297)[\[298\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-26_Jan-298) - More than a thousand women staged a sit-in protest at Frazer Town in Bangalore for 48 hours.[\[299\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-25_January_2020-299) - **26 January** - More than 300 eminent personalities in India including actor [Naseeruddin Shah](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naseeruddin_Shah), [Javed Jaffrey](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Javed_Jaffrey), and film-maker [Mira Nair](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mira_Nair) signed and issued an open statement against the CAA.[\[300\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-26_Jan_300_sign-300) - On the occasion of [Republic Day](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republic_Day_(India)), protests were held in Delhi,[\[301\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-301) Mumbai, Hyderabad, Chicago,[\[302\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-302) and London.[\[303\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-303) - 6-7 million people participated in a [human chain](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_chain_(politics)) extending from [Kasaragod](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kasaragod) to [Kaliyikkavila](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kaliyakkavilai) organised by the [LDF](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Left_Democratic_Front_(Kerala)) in Kerala.[\[304\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-:1-304) - **30 January** - A [juvenile](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juvenile_delinquency) [Hindu fundamentalist](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindu_nationalism) opened fire at a protest at the [Jamia Milia Islamia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Millia_Islamia), injuring one student.[\[305\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-305)[\[306\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-:0-306)[\[307\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-307) The event happened on the 72nd anniversary of the [assassination of Mahatma Gandhi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_of_Mahatma_Gandhi), also by a Hindu fundamentalist. He was arrested and charged with attempted murder.[\[308\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-308) The man shouted slogans of " _[Jai Shri Ram](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jai_Shri_Ram)_" (Victory to Lord Rama) and " _Delhi Police Zindabad_" (Long live Delhi police).[\[309\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-309) - Bihar Police detained CPI leader [Kanhaiya Kumar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kanhaiya_Kumar) before he could start his planned month-long "Jan-Gana-Man Yatra" which was organised at [Champaran](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Champaran) on [Mahatma Gandhi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi)'s death anniversary.[\[310\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-310) - Seven protesters who were protesting at the Ghantaghar (Clock Tower) in Lucknow. They were arrested for taking out a candle march, which UP Police said was a violation of section 144 of the CrPC which was imposed in the area.[\[311\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-311) - **31 January** - Leaders from 14 opposition parties, led by the Indian National Congress, wore black armbands and vacated the front row seats to protest against the new law, the NRC and the NPR during President [Ram Nath Kovind](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ram_Nath_Kovind)'s address to the [Joint Session of the Parliament of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joint_Session_of_the_Parliament_of_India) for [2020 budget](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Union_budget_of_India) session. The Leader of the Opposition in the [Rajya Sabha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rajya_Sabha), [Ghulam Nabi Azad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ghulam_Nabi_Azad) said that the Union Government misused the President's office and it was "shameful" that the government had included the CAA in the President's speech as an achievement.[\[312\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-312) ### February 2020 [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=7) - **1 February** - After the JMI firing incident on 30 January, another Hindu fundamentalist fired bullets in the air during the [Shaheen Bagh protests](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaheen_Bagh_protests).[\[313\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-:3-313) The man chanted the slogans " _Hindu Rashtra Zindabad_" (Long live the [Hindu Rashtra](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindu_nationalism))[\[313\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-:3-313) and " _Sirf Hinduo ki chalegi_" (Only Hindus will rule in this country).[\[314\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-314) - [Amnesty International](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amnesty_International) informed US lawmakers that the CAA clearly violates the Constitution of India and [International human rights law](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_human_rights_law) and "legitimises discrimination" on the basis of religion.[\[315\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-315) - Thousands of LGBT rights activists protest raised slogans against the CAA at the [Queer Azaadi Pride Parade](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queer_Azaadi_Mumbai) in Mumbai.[\[316\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-316)[\[317\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-317) - **6 February** - In [Bidar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bidar), a mother and a school principal were arrested after the mother's daughter participated in a play against the CAA.[\[318\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-318) - **7 February** - The Bidar police interrogated 85 school-children studying in classes 4–6 for participating in an anti-CAA play.[\[319\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-319) - Ahead of the [2020 Delhi Legislative Assembly election](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Delhi_Legislative_Assembly_election), two bike-borne men allegedly opened fired in the air near an anti-Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) protest site in Northeast Delhi's Jafrabad. The police, however, suspected personal enmity.[\[320\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-320) - **8 February** - A Muslim BJP councillor in [Indore](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indore) resigned from the party, accusing it of spreading "politics of hatred".[\[321\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-321) - **11 February** - [Jamia Milia Islamia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Millia_Islamia) students staged a march to the [Parliament](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parliament_of_India) against the CAA and NRC. The march was stopped by the Delhi police who detained protesters.[\[322\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-322) The police allegedly sexually assaulted the protesters.[\[323\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-323) - **16 February** - [Imran Pratapgarhi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mohammad_Imran_Pratapgarhi), an Indian National Congress politician was fined ₹1.04 [crore](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crore) (equivalent to ₹1.2 crore or US$147,000 in 2023) for violating Section 144 by addressing protestors, participating in an anti-CAA protest in [Moradabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moradabad), Uttar Pradesh, and allegedly instigating protesters at the Idgah ground.[\[324\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-324) - **17 February** - Over 150 prominent citizens including former judges, bureaucrats, army officers and academicians wrote to President Ram Nath Kovind, claiming that the anti-CAA protests were based on a false narrative, and urged the centre to look into the ongoing protests with all seriousness, safeguard the nation's democratic institutions and take stern action against the people behind them.[\[325\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-325)[\[326\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-326)[\[327\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-327) - [Magsaysay Award](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramon_Magsaysay_Award) recipient [Sandeep Pandey](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sandeep_Pandey) was arrested by the Lucknow police for attempting to protest. He was released on bail after being produced in the District Magistrate's court.[\[328\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-328) - **18 February** - The Uttar Pradesh government informed the [Allahabad High Court](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allahabad_High_Court) that 22 had been killed in the protests and a total of 883 people had been arrested in connection with violence during the protests.[\[329\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-329) - **19 February** - [Secretary-General of the United Nations](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secretary-General_of_the_United_Nations) [António Guterres](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ant%C3%B3nio_Guterres) expressed concerns over the possibility of millions being rendered [stateless](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stateless_nation) due to the CAA and NRC.[\[330\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-330)[\[331\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-331) - In [Chennai](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chennai), a confederation of Muslim groups led a massive rally towards the [Secretariat](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secretariat_(administrative_office)) of Tamil Nadu in a demonstration against the CAA. It came a day after the [Madras High Court](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madras_High_Court) denied permission to protesters to protest near[\[332\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-332) the state assembly and press for passage of a resolution against CAA, NRC and NPR. - **20 February** - [All India Majlis-e-Ittehadul Muslimeen](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_India_Majlis-e-Ittehadul_Muslimeen) leader and spokesperson [Waris Pathan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waris_Pathan) stoked controversy at a rally in Karnataka's [Gulbarga](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gulbarga) district by stating "To those saying we have only put our women at the forefront – only the lionesses are out and you're already sweating. Imagine what would happen if we all came together. We are 15 crore, but that can outweigh 100 crore, remember that."[\[333\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-333) The politician withdrew his statement on 23 February, saying that he had no intentions of hurting the sentiments of any community,[\[334\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-334) after criticism from both the ruling and opposition parties.[\[335\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-335) - **22 February** - About 200 Women gathered near the Jaffrabad Metro Station in Delhi at night protesting against the CAA and NRC.[\[336\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-336) - [Chief Minister of Maharashtra](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_Minister_of_Maharashtra) [Uddhav Thackeray](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uddhav_Thackeray) decided to not pass a resolution against the CAA, making [Maharashtra](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maharashtra) the first [UPA](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Progressive_Alliance)-ruled state to decide not to pass a resolution.[\[337\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-337) - **23 February** - The protest in the Jaffrabad Metro Station continued for the second day. Around 500 people mostly women gathered around the metro station that leads to closing the entry and exit from the metro station.[\[338\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-338)[\[339\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-339) - **24 February** The burnt shops at Shiv Vihar in [North East Delhi riots](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_East_Delhi_riots). - One policeman and four protestors were killed and several shops and vehicles were burnt during a violent protest in Delhi.[\[340\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-:4-340) - 13 people were killed in the [North East Delhi riots](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_East_Delhi_riots).[\[341\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_News-341) - **25 February** - A shoot-at-sight order was issued in the evening by [Delhi Police](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_Police) after the Anti-CAA and Pro-CAA protests became violent.[\[342\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-342) - The [Central Board of Secondary Education](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Board_of_Secondary_Education) postponed board examinations for classes 10 and 12 in northeast Delhi, in view of ongoing riots in the area. However, exams for the rest of Delhi and India would be conducted as per schedule.[\[343\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-343)[\[344\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-344) - **26 February** - The [Delhi High Court](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_High_Court) in an emergency late-night hearing, asked the police to ensure safe passage for those injured in the [North East Delhi riots](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_East_Delhi_riots) to the hospitals.[\[345\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-345) - The Delhi High Court asked the police to file [First information reports](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_information_report) against various politicians who were involved in making inflammatory speeches, provoking rioters in North East Delhi.[\[346\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-346) - **27 February** - One day after Delhi High Court judge [S. Muralidhar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/S._Muralidhar) directed Delhi police to file an FIR against those who had made inflammatory speeches, the [President of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_India) ordered his transfer with the recommendation of [Supreme Court of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_India).[\[347\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-347) ### March 2020 [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=8) - **3 March** - The [UN High Commissioner](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Office_of_the_United_Nations_High_Commissioner_for_Human_Rights) filed an intervention application in the Supreme Court to be made a party in the case.[\[348\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-UN_moves_to_SC-348) ### 2024 [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=9) - **3 March** In response to the perceived lack of action by existing student unions, a new initiative called the Wesean Student Federation (WSF) was formed in March 2024.[\[349\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-349)[\[350\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-350) The WSF and other organisations like the Naga Student Federation has also sought international intervention on the issue, urging the [United Nations](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations_Permanent_Forum_on_Indigenous_Issues) to address the discriminatory nature of the CAA and its potential threat to the sovereignty and rights of indigenous peoples in the region. [\[351\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-351)[\[352\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-352) ## Resolutions [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=10) So far, at least eight states have announced that they will not implement the Act or the [National Register of Citizens](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens) (NRC). While one state and two [Union Territories](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Union_Territories)[\[353\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-353) have refused to implement the CAA, three other states[\[354\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-354)[\[355\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-355) have only declined the implementation of the NRC. However, the [Union Home Ministry](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ministry_of_Home_Affairs_(India)) said that states lack the legal power to stop the implementation of Citizenship Amendment Act. ### Resolutions against CAA [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=11) - A resolution to scrap the CAA was moved by Chief Minister of Kerala, [Pinarayi Vijayan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinarayi_Vijayan) in the [Kerala Legislative Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerala_Legislative_Assembly). It was eventually passed by an absolute majority, with only the lone BJP MLA voting against it.[\[356\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-356) - The [Pattali Makkal Katchi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pattali_Makkal_Katchi), a member of the BJP-led [National Democratic Alliance](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Democratic_Alliance) passed a resolution against the NRC. It had urged the Central Government and the State [Government of Tamil Nadu](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_of_Tamil_Nadu) not to extend the NRC in the state citing that it would create tension and fear in the society.[\[357\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-357) - The [Punjab Legislative Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punjab_Legislative_Assembly), that has the Indian National Congress in the majority, passed a resolution against the Act and urged the Modi Government to avoid discrimination on the basis of religion through the new Act. The resolution was moved by Punjab minister for parliamentary affairs [Brahm Mohindra](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brahm_Mohindra) of the [Congress](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_National_Congress) and was supported by the [Aam Aadmi Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aam_Aadmi_Party) and the [Lok Insaaf Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lok_Insaaf_Party).[\[358\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-358) - The [Rajasthan Legislative Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rajasthan_Legislative_Assembly) that has the Indian National Congress in the majority, passed a resolution asking the Central government to repeal the CAA, making Rajasthan the third state to do so after Kerala and Punjab.[\[359\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Rajasthan_Assembly-359) - A resolution to repeal the CAA was moved in the [West Bengal Legislative Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Bengal_Legislative_Assembly) by the [All India Trinamool Congress](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_India_Trinamool_Congress) headed by the Chief Minister, [Mamata Banerjee](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mamata_Banerjee) and eventually got passed on 27 January 2020, becoming the fourth state assembly to do so.[\[360\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-360) The West Bengal Assembly had also previously passed a resolution against the NRC in September 2019 and the first state assembly to pass a resolution against the proposed NRC.[\[361\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-361) - A five-page resolution against the CAA was drafted by 154 members of the [European Parliament](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Parliament),[\[362\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-362) who stated that it "marks a dangerous shift in the way citizenship will be determined in India and is set to create the largest statelessness crisis in the world and cause immense human suffering".[\[363\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Statelessness_Crisis-363) - The [Madhya Pradesh Legislative Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madhya_Pradesh_Legislative_Assembly) passed a resolution against the CAA, becoming the fifth state to do so, after Rajasthan, West Bengal, Kerala and Punjab.[\[364\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-364) - The [Bihar Legislative Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bihar_Legislative_Assembly) on 25 February 2020 unanimously passed a resolution not to implement the NRC in the State. It also said the NPR would be implemented in Bihar in the old 2010 format.[\[365\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-365)[\[366\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-366) - The [National Assembly of Pakistan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Assembly_of_Pakistan) passed a resolution labelling the Act as a "discriminatory law" and argued that it contravened "bilateral agreements and understandings between India and Pakistan, particularly those on security and rights of minorities in the respective countries".[\[367\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-367) - On 12 February 2020, [Puducherry Legislative Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Puducherry_Legislative_Assembly) passed a resolution against the amended Citizenship Act, becoming the first union territory in the country to say no to the new law. The resolution passed by the Congress-led government in Puducherry also opposed the NRC and the NPR.[\[368\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-368)[\[369\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-369) - The [Gram panchayat](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gram_panchayat) of Islak, of [Ahmednagar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ahmednagar_district), Maharastra passed a resolution in January 2020 against the CAA, the NRC and the NPR, becoming the first Indian Gram Panchayat to do so. After Islak, Ghatnandur of [Ambajogai](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ambajogai), Maharastra, Loutolim of Goa and the panchayat of Patrud village of [Beed](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beed_district), Maharastra have passed a resolutions against the CAA.[\[370\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-370)[\[371\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-371)[\[372\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-372)[\[373\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-373) - On 13 March 2020, The [Delhi Legislative Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_Legislative_Assembly) passed a resolution against the CAA, becoming the second union territory to do so, after Puducherry.[\[374\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-374)[\[375\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-375) - The [Telangana Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telangana_Assembly) has passed a resolution opposing the CAA, the NPR and the NRC moved by the [Telangana Rashtra Samithi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telangana_Rashtra_Samithi) headed by the Chief minister [K. Chandrashekar Rao](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/K._Chandrashekar_Rao). It has emerged as the 7th state to take decisions against the CAA, NPR and NCR. The resolution stated the Act as unconstitutional and urged the Union Government to remove all references to religion and any particular country.[\[376\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-376)[\[377\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-377) - Several US cities and counties — Seattle, Albany, St. Paul, Hamtramck, Cambridge, San Francisco, Riverdale and Alameda County — have passed resolutions against the CAA and NRC.[\[378\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Seattle_City_Council_Resolution-378)[\[379\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-379)[\[380\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-380)[\[381\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-381)[\[382\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-382) - On 13 July 2020, [New Westminster](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Westminster) in the province of British Columbia, Canada passed a resolution against CAA and urged the Canadian government to "take a position in opposition."[\[383\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-383)[\[384\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-384) - The [Sree Sankaracharya University of Sanskrit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sree_Sankaracharya_University_of_Sanskrit) (SSUS) at [Kalady](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kalady) in [Kerala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerala) become the first university in the country to pass a resolution against the Citizenship Amendment Act by its syndicate in January 2020.[\[385\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-385) This was followed by [Calicut University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calicut_University) in the same month.[\[386\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-386) ## Protests [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=12) After the bill was approved on 4 December 2019, violent protests erupted in Assam, especially in [Guwahati](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guwahati), and other areas in the state.[\[132\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ET_CAA_12-132) Reactionary protests were held as well in several metropolitan cities across India, including Delhi,[\[387\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-387) [Bangalore](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bangalore),[\[388\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-388) [Ahmedabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ahmedabad), [Hyderabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyderabad),[\[389\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-389) [Jaipur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaipur), [Kolkata](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kolkata) and [Mumbai](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mumbai).[\[390\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-DC-HYD-390)[\[391\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-391) Reactionary protests were also held at universities across the country including [Cotton University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cotton_University),[\[392\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-392) [Gauhati University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gauhati_University),[\[393\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-393) [IIT Bombay](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Technology_Bombay),[\[390\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-DC-HYD-390) [Madras University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madras_University),[\[394\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-394) [Presidency University, Kolkata](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presidency_University,_Kolkata),[\[395\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-395) [Jamia Millia Islamia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Millia_Islamia),[\[396\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-396)[\[397\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-397) [Osmania University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osmania_University),[\[398\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-398) [University of Hyderabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Hyderabad), [University of Delhi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Delhi),[\[399\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-399) [Panjab University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panjab_University)[\[400\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-400) and [Aligarh Muslim University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aligarh_Muslim_University).[\[401\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-401) By 16 December, the protests had spread across India with demonstrations occurring in at least 17 cities including [Chennai](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chennai), [Jaipur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaipur), [Bhopal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhopal), [Lucknow](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucknow) and [Puducherry](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pondicherry).[\[402\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-402)[\[403\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-403)[\[404\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Washington_Post_16-404) Between 16 and 18 December, a statement of solidarity "condemning the recent police action and brutalization of students at Jamia Millia University and Aligarh Muslim University" had acquired 10,293 signatories from over 1,100 universities, colleges and academic institutions across the world. Scholars from major academic institutions in India, including [JNU](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/JNU_Delhi), [Delhi University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_University), all the [Indian Institutes of Technology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institutes_of_Technology), the [Indian Statistical Institute](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Statistical_Institute), the [Tata Institute of Fundamental Research](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tata_Institute_of_Fundamental_Research), among many others had signed the solidarity statement.[\[94\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CaravanAuthoritarianism-94) On 16 December, professors and students of [IIM-Ahmedabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Management_Ahmedabad) were detained by police citing demonstrating protest against the Act is illegal.[\[405\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-405) On 19 December police banned protests in several parts of India with the imposition of [Section 144](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unlawful_assembly#India) which prohibits the gathering of more than 4 individuals in a public space as being unlawful, namely, parts of the capital [New Delhi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi), Uttar Pradesh, and [Karnataka](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karnataka), including Bangalore. As Section 144 was imposed, the students of [IIM-Bangalore](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Management_Bangalore) demonstrate their protest peacefully by laying shoes and placards in front of the institute gate, which they called the Shoe [Satyagraha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satyagraha).[\[406\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-406) Following IIM-Ahmedabad and Bangalore, [IIM-Calcutta](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Management_Calcutta) raised their voice peacefully in solidarity against the Act and the brutal misconduct by police against the students who were protesting all over the country.[\[407\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-407) Several institutes in [Kozhikode](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kozhikode) including [IIM-Kozhikode](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Management_Kozhikode), [NIT-Calicut](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Institute_of_Technology_Calicut), [Government Medical College, Kozhikode](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_Medical_College,_Kozhikode) and [Farook College](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Farook_College) expressed their protest from 19 to 20 December.[\[408\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-408) Police in [Chennai](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chennai) denied permission for marches, rallies or any other demonstration.[\[409\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-409)[\[410\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-410) Internet services were also shutdown in some parts of Delhi. As a result of defying the ban, thousands of protesters were detained, primarily in Delhi, including several opposition leaders and activists such as [Ramachandra Guha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramachandra_Guha), [Sitaram Yechury](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sitaram_Yechury), [Yogendra Yadav](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yogendra_Yadav), [Umar Khalid](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Umar_Khalid), [Sandeep Dikshit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sandeep_Dikshit), and [D Raja](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/D_Raja).[\[411\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-411)[\[412\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-412)[\[413\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-413) Despite the fear of being detained, tens of thousands of people protested in Hyderabad, Patna, Chandigarh, Mumbai and other cities. Civil society groups, political parties, students, activists and ordinary citizens used social medial platforms to ask people to turn up and protest peacefully.[\[172\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_19_Dec-172) The protests involving 20,000 protesters concluded peacefully at the [August Kranti Maidan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/August_Kranti_Maidan) at Mumbai.[\[179\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Mumbai_Mirror_19-179) More than 300 eminent personalities in India signed and issued an open statement against the CAA. The signatories including actor [Naseeruddin Shah](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naseeruddin_Shah), Ratna Patak Shah, Jaaved Jafferi, Nandita Das, Lillete Dubey film-maker [Mira Nair](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mira_Nair), writers Anita Desai, Kiran Desai, actors, sociologist Ashis Nandy, activists Sohail Hashmi and Shabnam Hashmi among others.[\[300\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-26_Jan_300_sign-300) ### Assam [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=13) Mass Gathering of Anti Citizenship Act protests at Chandmari, [Guwahati](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guwahati), AssamA [Rangoli](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rangoli) created as a part of protests against anti Citizenship Act 2019 at Chandmari, [Guwahati](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guwahati), Assam Students of [Cotton University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cotton_University) began protesting against the CAA a few days before the controversial bill was produced on the floor of the [Lok Sabha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lok_Sabha). On 29 November, the students staged a silent protest outside the university campus.[\[414\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-414)[\[415\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-415) After the bill was cleared on 4 December 2019, violent protests erupted in Assam, especially in [Guwahati](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guwahati), and other areas in the state.[\[132\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ET_CAA_12-132) _[Reuters](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reuters)_ reported that the protests in the state were violent, adding that at least two people were killed till 16 December. Buildings and railway stations were set on fire. The CAA made 2014 as the cut-off date to determine illegal foreigners but according to people opposing the act, Assam bore the brunt of immigrants from 1951 to 1971, while other states did not.[\[416\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-416)[\[417\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-417)[\[418\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-418) The protesters were angry that the new law would allow thousands of [Bengali](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bengali_language) speaking non-Muslim [immigrants from Bangladesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Illegal_immigration_to_India#Bangladeshi_immigrants) to become legal citizens of India,[\[155\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Reuters16Dec-155)[\[130\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-bbc-130) thereby influencing the political and cultural environment of Assam.[\[419\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-419) Thousands of members and workers of the [All Assam Students Union (AASU)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_Assam_Students%27_Union) and 30 other indigenous organisations, artists, cultural activists of the state gathered at Latasil ground in Dispur to stage a [satyagraha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satyagraha) against the Act on 16, 17 and 18 December.[\[420\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-420)[\[162\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ITAASU-162) [Assam Police](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Police) subsequently detained the general secretary and the [adviser](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adviser) to the AASU and over 2,000 protesters in Guwahati during a protest rally on 18 December.[\[421\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-421)[\[422\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-422) On 12 December, security personnel, including [CRPF](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Reserve_Police_Force) jawans with batons and shields barged into the office of a private TV channel of Assam, _[Prag News](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prag_News)_ in Guwahati and attacked its staffers with batons during protests.[\[423\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-423) On 20 December, [Assamese language](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assamese_language) newspapers reported violent incidents occurring during the protests across the state. Use of excessive force by the police was also reported.[\[424\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-424) In [Dibrugarh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dibrugarh), the All Assam Students Union members vandalised the district office of the [Asom Gana Parishad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asom_Gana_Parishad), which had voted in favour of the act as part of the ruling Coalition.[\[425\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-HBL-425)[\[426\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-426) Peasant leader [Akhil Gogoi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Akhil_Gogoi) was arrested in [Jorhat](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jorhat) on 12 December as a preventive measure by authorities to prevent him from organising any protests. A special court of [National Investigation Agency](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Investigation_Agency) (NIA) in Guwahati on Tuesday charged him under [sedition](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sedition) for " [maoist](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maoism) links" and sent him to 10-day NIA custody. The [Assam Human rights Commission](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Human_rights_Commission) decided to take suo moto cognizance of reports of alleged torture upon Akhil Gogoi.[\[427\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-427)[\[428\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-428) According to the [Assam Government](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Government), people have been arrested by the Assam Police for their alleged involvement in the violent incidents during the anti-CAA protests across the state, as of 17 December.[\[146\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ITAkhil19-146)[\[429\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-429) In [Dispur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dispur), several thousands of protesters broke down police barricades to protest in front of the [Assam Legislative Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Legislative_Assembly) building.[\[430\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-430)[\[134\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-New_York_Times-134) Demonstrations were also held in [Agartala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agartala).[\[431\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-431) On 15 December 2019, a concert was staged by artistes of Assam as a protest against the CAA. The concert was themed as 'No CAA, Concert for peace and harmony'. Along with music, paintings were also demonstrated in the event.[\[432\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-432)[\[433\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-433) Access to the internet was restricted in Assam by the administrative authorities.[\[103\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_arrests-103) A curfew was also declared in Assam and [Tripura](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tripura) due to the protests,[\[130\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-bbc-130) leading to army deployment as protesters defied the curfews. Railway services were suspended and some airlines started to waive rescheduling or cancellation fees in those areas.[\[95\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_2_Dead-95) Officials reported that at least four people died after clashes with police in [Guwahati](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guwahati).[\[434\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-434)[\[95\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_2_Dead-95) Two men, Dipanjal Das and Sam Stafford, died due to police firing on 12 December.[\[145\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto3-145)[\[435\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-435) On 15 December, [Gauhati Medical College and Hospital](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gauhati_Medical_College_and_Hospital) official stated that Ishwar Nayak died on the night of 14 December and Abdul Alim died on 15 December morning. Both of them had been admitted to the hospital after suffering gunshot wounds.[\[149\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-quint_CAA-149) As of 15 December, it was reported that at least 6 people had died due to police firing during the protests.[\[436\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-436) After ten days of restriction, mobile internet services in the state were restored from 20 December, although the [Gauhati High Court](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gauhati_High_Court) had ordered the government of Assam to restore the service by 5 pm on 19 December.[\[437\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-437) By 22 December, the number of arrested people rose to 393, with 28 cases being registered for making offensive and provocative posts on social media.[\[438\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto4-438) On 21 December, an all-woman protest was organised across the state.[\[184\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ReutersHundreds-184) Senior citizens across the state protested on 23 December.[\[439\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-439) Chowkidinghee playground in [Dibrugarh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dibrugarh_district) saw one of the largest mass gatherings of CAA protests in Assam organised by All Assam Students' Union on 24 December.[\[440\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-440) On 8 January, PM Modi cancelled his visit to Assam while the protests continued in the state. AASU had planned huge protests during Modi's visit.[\[240\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TNIE_Modi_8_Jan-240)[\[241\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Outlook_8_Jan-241) Thousands of people joined the anti-CAA protests at Dibrugarh, Guwahati and other parts of Assam.[\[242\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Telegraph_8_January-242) The protesters dressed up in traditional dress of the region and sang devotional songs during the protest. The protesters also demanded the release of Akhil Gogoi and called the [Modi government](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modi_government) a dictatorship.[\[243\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-nenow_8_January_2020-243) On 9 January, musical protests were planned at Gauhati Club in Assam by AASU, along with 30 other organisations and artist communities.[\[242\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Telegraph_8_January-242) On 22 January, thousands of students from 9 universities in North East India boycotted classes and joined a protest march in the states of Assam, [Nagaland](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nagaland), Meghalaya and [Arunachal Pradesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arunachal_Pradesh).[\[284\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-HT_22_Jan_Assam-284) ### Tripura [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=14) Several protests marches with thousands of protesters were held in Tripura. On 12 December _BBC_ reported that the army had been deployed in the state and around 1800 people were arrested.[\[95\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_2_Dead-95) Around 200 protesters were detained by police during a protest in the capital city of [Agartala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agartala).[\[441\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-441) On 11 December, [Pradyot Manikya Debbarma](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pradyot_Manikya_Debbarma), the royal scion, led the largest protest in Tripura so far consisting of thousands of people.[\[252\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_12_Jan-252) Debbarma stated that beneficiaries of CAA would not be allowed to settle in Tripura. He added that the state has already accommodated many migrants from [East Pakistan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Pakistan) and further immigration due to CAA would endanger the threatened indigenous residents of the state.[\[252\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_12_Jan-252) The Act also ignited old conflicts between the Bengalis and the [Reang refugees](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reang#The_Displaced_Reangs). Fresh clashes were reported in the northern district of [Kanchanpur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kanchanpur_District) between the two communities. The Reang refugees were protesting against the CAA while the Hindu Bengalis were supporting it. Protesters reportedly threw stones and vandalised shops and a marketplace.[\[442\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-442) ### Crackdown on Universities [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=15) #### Jamia Millia Islamia [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=16) Main article: [2019 Jamia Milia Islamia attack](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Jamia_Milia_Islamia_attack) On 13 December 2019, the students of [Jamia Millia Islamia University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Millia_Islamia_University) undertook a march to the Parliament protesting against the CAA. They were prevented from going ahead by the police who used batons and tear gas to disperse the protesters leading to clashes with them. Fifty students were detained by the police after the clash. According to the students, police attacked the peaceful protesters with stones and sticks, and several students were injured. The students then retaliated, and clashes ensued. Police denied the allegations, also claiming that the protesters attacked the policemen with stones after they were stopped from marching onwards. Police then used tear gas to disperse them.[\[443\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-The_Hindu_13_Jamia-443) On the morning of 15 December 2019, more than two thousand students of Jamia joined the protests against CAA in Delhi.[\[444\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CNN_spread-444) Jamia Millia Student Body and Jamia Millia Islamia Teacher's Association (JTA) condemned the violence that happened on the same day in Delhi and stated that no student or teacher was involved in the violence.[\[149\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-quint_CAA-149) At 6:46 pm on 15 December 2019, hundreds of police officers forcefully entered the campus of Jamia, without the permission of college authority.[\[149\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-quint_CAA-149) The police used batons and tear gas on the protesting students.[\[404\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Washington_Post_16-404) Nearly a hundred students were detained by the Delhi police and released at 3:30 am next morning.[\[445\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Police_station-445) The visuals of students being dragged and [assaulted](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assaulted) by the police was telecast by news channels. Students from all across Delhi joined the agitation.[\[446\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-446) About two hundred people were injured[\[404\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Washington_Post_16-404) and were admitted to [AIIMS](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_India_Institute_of_Medical_Sciences,_New_Delhi) and the [Holy Family Hospital](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Holy_Family_Hospital_(New_Delhi)&action=edit&redlink=1).[\[447\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TNIE_Jamia_16-447) Anti-CAA Banner demonstrated at Cultural Protest organised by Artistes of Assam at AEI ground, Chandmari, [Guwahati](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guwahati). On 16 December 2019, two students of Jamia were admitted to the [Safdarjung Hospital](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Safdarjung_Hospital) with bullet injuries received during the protests on 15 December.[\[404\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Washington_Post_16-404) One of the victims, M. Tamin stated that he was not participating in the protest and was passing through the area on a motorcycle, when police suddenly started caning the protesters and he was shot in the leg by police from point blank range.[\[448\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-India_Today_Tamin-448) According to the doctors treating him, the wounds were from a gunshot.[\[449\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-449)[\[450\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-450)\[ _[non-primary source needed](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research#Primary,_secondary_and_tertiary_sources)_\] The police stated that they were investigating the allegations of gunshot.[\[447\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TNIE_Jamia_16-447) The vice-chancellor stated that they will file a court case against the police, demanding an investigation on how police entered the university premises and assaulted the students.[\[79\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_Plea-79)[\[155\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Reuters16Dec-155) On 15 December, Delhi Police attacked students of Jamia Millia Islamia including Shaheen Abdullah, Chanda Yadav, Ladeeda Farzana and [Aysha Renna](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aysha_Renna) at New Friends Colony.[\[451\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-451) The university was shut until 5 January 2020 and the residents were asked to leave the campus.[\[452\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-HinduLiveCAA-452) Response The police violence was heavily criticised by filmmaker [Anurag Kashyap](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anurag_Kashyap), actor [John Cusack](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Cusack) and [Rajkummar Rao](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rajkummar_Rao) condemned the police violence, with Cusack referring it to [fascism](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fascism) and Kashyap calling the government to be "clearly fascist".[\[453\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Kashyap-453)[\[454\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-454) Actor [Swara Bhaskar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swara_Bhaskar), praised the students protests for raising their voice against communalism and called the police action as dictatorial, brutal, shocking and shameful. She also questioned if it was the police and not the protesters who vandalised the property in Delhi and Aligarh.[\[455\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Swara-455) [Amnesty International India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amnesty_International_India) criticised the police for the violence against the students of Jamia and Aligarh University and stated that the allegations of police brutality and sexual harassment against the students should be investigated and culprits be punished. Defending the right of the students to protest, its director stated that the arrest of protesters violate India's obligations under the Article 19 and Article 21 of the [International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Covenant_on_Civil_and_Political_Rights) (ICCPR), to respect and protect the right to freedom of expression and peaceful assembly.[\[452\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-HinduLiveCAA-452) _No to police brutality graffiti_ on a metro wall in New Delhi In response to the police crackdown in Jamia Millia Islamia University and Aligarh Muslim University, protests were also joined by the students of the educational institutions of [IIT Kanpur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/IIT,_Kanpur), [IIT Madras](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/IIT_Madras), [Jadavpur University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jadavpur_University), [Tata Institute of Social Sciences](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tata_Institute_of_Social_Sciences,_Hyderabad), [IISc](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Science_(IISc),_Bangalore), [Pondicherry University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pondicherry_University), [IIM Ahmedabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Management_Ahmedabad),[\[456\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-456) as well as organisations such as [Pinjra Tod](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinjra_Tod) and the [Students' Federation of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Students%27_Federation_of_India).[\[457\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BSDelhiCondemn-457) The students of Jadavpur University, West Bengal, called a protest gathering on 16 December, to "condemn the brutal [state terror](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_terrorism) on the students of Jamia Millia Islamia University".[\[458\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-thenewsminute-458) At the event of IIT Kanpur, communal slogans were also raised by the protesters.[\[459\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-459) A placard on the 23rd day of [protests at Shaheen Bagh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaheen_Bagh_protests); in solidarity with AMU JMI JNU, 8 January 2020 in New Delhi .Aftermath On 17 December, police arrested ten people (some of them having criminal history) in the case of the violent clashes in Jamia. None of the arrested were students of Jamia.[\[460\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_10_arrested-460) On 13 January, several student groups protested outside the office of Vice-Chancellor asking to reschedule the exam dates, filing a case against Delhi Police and ensuring the safety of students. The VC announced in the afternoon, that a case will be filed against police on 14 January.[\[254\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CAA_live_13_Jan-254) On 15 January, the VC met Delhi police commissioner to discuss the violence and urged him to file an FIR.[\[263\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Wire_Guj_15_Jan-263) The Registrar of JMI filed a petition in a Delhi court for filing FIR on the violence at JMI. The court directed Delhi Police to submit by 16 March, a report on the actions taken on JMI administration's complaint.[\[461\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-23_Jan_JMI_report-461) #### Aligarh Muslim University [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=17) On 15 December, protests against CAA were held outside the campus of the [Aligarh Muslim University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aligarh_Muslim_University).[\[462\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-462) On the evening of 15 December, police officers forcefully entered the campus of the university and assaulted the students. At least 60 students were injured including the president of the students Union. The access to the internet was restricted in the area by the district administration. The university was closed from 15 December till 5 January 2020.[\[157\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Aligarh-157) A report by three activist-lawyers alleged that the police had resorted to "deceptive shelling", firing explosives camouflaged as tear gas shells during the crackdown.[\[463\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-463) On the evening of 17 December, police released 26 people (including 8 students) on personal bonds. They had been arrested on charges of violence.[\[464\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_CAA_17_Dec-464) On 19 December, [People's Union for Democratic Rights](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/People%27s_Union_for_Democratic_Rights)' fact-finding team consisting of activists [Yogendra Yadav](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yogendra_Yadav), [Harsh Mander](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harsh_Mander) and [Kavita Krishnan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kavita_Krishnan) released a report on police crackdown at the Aligarh Muslim University. The report alleged that the police had called the students as terrorists and had used religiously charged slogans such as " _[Jai Shri Ram](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jai_Shri_Ram)_". The report also accused the police of breaking the protocols of the campus. It added that no bullet injury was reported. The report was prepared after visiting the campus, based on the video and audio clips of the incident, statements of the injured students and witnesses.[\[465\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-465) After a lull of four days, on 20 December, AMU campus again witnessed protests on Saturday with hundreds of AMU non-teaching staff joining hands with AMU teachers' association, protesting against the CAA and "police atrocities" against the agitators in various parts of the state.[\[466\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-News18Cops263-466) On 24 December 1000 – 1200 protesters were booked after organising a candle march inside [Aligarh Muslim University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aligarh_Muslim_University) for violating section 144.[\[203\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto7-203) On 15 January, Aligarh Muslim University postponed all exams due to the ongoing CAA protests.[\[266\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-AMU_postpones_exams_15_Jan-266) Aftermath At 7 am on 16 January, Vice-Chancellor met the protesting students and expressed regret for calling police inside the AMU campus to handle the law and order situation inside campus. He defended his decision stating he had not thought that the police would enter the hostels. AMU had set up a fact-finding committee headed by Justice (retd.) V.K. Gupta for a detailed investigation of the events that occurred in the night of 15 December. The VC asked to students to cooperate with the fact-finding committee and the National Human Rights Commission (NHRC) team that was visiting the campus.[\[467\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-AMU_V-C_16_Jan-467) #### Nadwa College [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=18) On 16 December, around 300 students of [Nadwa college](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nadwa_University), in Lucknow had planned a peaceful protest march against CAA and in solidarity with the students of AMU. The police prevented students from holding the march and forced them to return into the campus premises. The police locked the gates of the campus from outside and guarded it with a heavy deployment of police to prevent the students from coming out of the campus and undertaking the planned march.[\[160\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-HT_Nadwa-160) A clash between the police and the students locked inside the campus ensued and involved [stone pelting](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stone_pelting) from both sides.[\[468\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Nadwa_video-468)[\[469\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Stone_Pelting_Cops-469) The police officers were seen hitting the students with sticks as in the video footage of the incident telecast on news channels.[\[79\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_Plea-79)[\[470\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Nadwa-470) Around 15 to 20 students were injured. 30 students were charged by the police for attempt to murder, rioting etc. The police accused the students of blocking the road and engaging in violence by throwing stones.[\[161\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Exp_Nadwa_17_Dec-161) While the students claimed that the police had attacked the unarmed students who were holding a peaceful protest. The student stated that they were neither involved in any violence, nor did they block any roads and yet they were charged with batons. After the incident the college was shut down until 5 January, and the students were asked to leave the campus.[\[161\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Exp_Nadwa_17_Dec-161) #### Jawaharlal Nehru University [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=19) Main article: [2020 JNU Attack](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_JNU_Attack) On 5 January, at 6:30pm, a masked mob consisting of more than 60–100 people armed with rods and sticks attacked the campus of [Jawaharlal Nehru University, Delhi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru_University,_Delhi).[\[236\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Masked_JNU-236)[\[471\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-471) The assault and vandalism lasted for 3 hours, where the mob chanted slogans exclaiming the victims to be "naxalites" and "anti-national".[\[472\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-472) The mob assaulted journalists and social activist, [Yogendra Yadav](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yogendra_Yadav) in the presence of media and police, who attempted to enter the campus on receiving news of the incident.[\[473\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-473) The mob also punctured the tires of ambulances attending to the victims of the assault which had left more than 42 students and teachers as severely injured. Street lights were shut off by authorities during the incident. Students of the campus including the [JNUSU](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru_University_Students%27_Union) president, Aishe Ghosh who was brutally attacked on head and was hospitalised, alleged the police of intentional inaction as police were informed before the assault about unknown groups entering in the campus.[\[474\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-474)[\[475\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-475) Around 30 students who were members of the left wing groups were injured along with 12 teachers. Visually impaired students were also not spared from assault.[\[476\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-476) The students and left wing organisations accused the members of the BJP's student wing, [Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Akhil_Bharatiya_Vidyarthi_Parishad) of orchestrating the attacks, while ABVP accused the left wing organisations.[\[236\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Masked_JNU-236) Professors who tried to intervene and save the students were also attacked. The policemen inside the campus allegedly did nothing to stop the mob.[\[236\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Masked_JNU-236)[\[477\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_JNU_4_Jan-477) The assault was orchestrated through a WhatsApp group called "Unity against Left" which were traced through messages from members of the ABVP in the group.[\[478\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-478)[\[479\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-479) Students in Mumbai, launched a protest called "Occupy Gateway" late at night to protest against the assault.[\[480\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-480) As a reaction to the assault, protests occurred across the country and in several cities.[\[481\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-481) ### Delhi [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=20) Locals in New Delhi protest against CAAA major road in New Delhi has been blocked by anti CAA protests for over three weeks in the [Shaheen Bagh protests](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaheen_Bagh_protests). (pic taken on 7 January 2020).[\[482\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-482) On 14 December 2019, thousands of agitators packed into [Jantar Mantar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jantar_Mantar,_New_Delhi) Road, filling up a space estimated to be half the size of a football ground, as multiple demonstrations occurred against the CAA in Delhi.[\[150\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Telegraph_Jantar-150)[\[151\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Jantar-151) The next day in Delhi near New Friends Colony, three [Delhi Transport Corporation](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_Transport_Corporation) buses were torched.[\[153\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-:5-153)[\[149\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-quint_CAA-149) On 16 December, [Priyanka Gandhi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Priyanka_Gandhi) led a silent protest at the [India Gate](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/India_Gate) along with about three hundred congress workers to show solidarity with the students of Jamia Millia Islamia.[\[49\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Priyanka_Gandhi-49) On 17 December 2019, Delhi's Seelampur area had stone-throwing crowds face off against the police. The police retaliated with tear gas and batons, in which, according to local reports, several protesters and officers were injured. There were also reports of a police station being set on fire. According to police, buses were vandalised in the area.[\[164\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-bbc_Seelampur-164) On 19 December 2019, the administrative authorities imposed a ban against public gatherings in parts of Delhi.[\[169\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Shah_Meeting-169) 20 metro stations were closed to prevent the movement for protests.[\[168\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_3_lives-168) At least 700 flights were delayed and more than 20 cancelled due to traffic jams caused by police closing the roads to stifle protests.[\[174\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Flights-174) Protest meetings were held defying the ban in Red Fort and [Mandi House](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mandi_House).[\[169\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Shah_Meeting-169) Access to the mobile internet was restricted in certain places in Delhi.[\[169\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Shah_Meeting-169) Digital rights activists, who accessed and studied the order suspending internet in several areas in Delhi on 19 December, stated that it was not issued from the "right channels" and, therefore, was "illegal".[\[483\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto-483) Politicians [Yogendra Yadav](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yogendra_Yadav), [Sitaram Yechury](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sitaram_Yechury), [Nilotpal Basu](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nilotpal_Basu), [Brinda Karat](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brinda_Karat), [Ajay Maken](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ajay_Maken), [Brinda Karat](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brinda_Karat), [Prakash Karat](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prakash_Karat), [Sandeep Dikshit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sandeep_Dikshit), [Umar Khalid](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Umar_Khalid) and [D. Raja](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/D._Raja) along with around 1,200 protesters were detained by the police.[\[169\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Shah_Meeting-169)[\[168\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_3_lives-168)[\[484\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-484) On 20 December 2019, two Delhi Metro stations – [Jamia Millia Islamia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Millia_Islamia_metro_station) and [Jasola Vihar Shaheen Bagh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jasola_Vihar_Shaheen_Bagh_metro_station) were closed. Amid nationwide crackdown because of CAA, [Bhim Army](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhim_Army) Chief [Chandrashekhar Azad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chandrashekhar_Azad_(social_activist))'s permission for the march from Jama Masjid to [Jantar Mantar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jantar_Mantar) had been denied by [Delhi Police](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_Police). In spite of the denial of permission and the imposition of [Section 144](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Section_144), a protest march was held where Azad was able to escape after being detained by the police.[\[181\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Bhim-181)[\[485\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-485) The protests were peaceful throughout the day, but in the evening a car was torched in Daryaganj after which the police attacked the protesters with water cannons and lathi charge.[\[486\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_6_killed-486) On the aftermath, Chandrashekhar Azad accused the [Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rashtriya_Swayamsevak_Sangh) of being responsible for the violence and sought for the resignation of the [Union Home Minister](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Union_Home_Minister), Amit Shah.[\[487\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-487) On 21 December, Chandrashekhar Azad was arrested along with 27 people and three FIRs were registered for the violent incidents on 20 December at Delhi Gate and Seemapuri.[\[182\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_16_Killed-182) On 10 January 12 of those arrested were released on bail.[\[488\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TH_released_10_Jan-488) On 15 January, a Delhi court granted bail and released Chandrashekhar Azad aka "Raavan".[\[265\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Azad_bail_15_Jan-265) However, when presented in the Delhi Tis Hazari court on 14 January 2020, the court questioned the public prosecutor about what is wrong with protesting since many people who protested in past are sitting chairpersons in the present government.[\[489\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-489) Protests were conducted by the journalists against the police brutality on the journalists covering the Anti-CAA protests especially in the states of Delhi, Uttar Pradesh and Karnataka. In the protests, [Sitaram Yechury](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sitaram_Yechury) stated that only the states ruled by the [Bharatiya Janata Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party) were experiencing violence. He further added that the other states were peaceful and hinted that the differences between the situation in the states show the who were encouraging violence.[\[490\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-490) On 23 December 2019, protests were held at multiple locations. 93 other students protesting outside Assam Bhawan and demanding the release of RTI activist Akhil Gogoi were detained by the police. The students alleged that the police used violence on the protesters.[\[491\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto5-491)[\[492\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-492) On 24 December 2019, Police imposed a ban on gatherings in central Delhi's [Mandi House](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mandi_House) near the Lutyens' Zone to prevent the protest march of students from multiple universities.
