The anti CAA-NRC protest march was to start from Mandi House to [Jantar Mantar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jantar_Mantar).[\[493\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-493)[\[494\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-494) On 27 December, the Delhi Police used [facial recognition software](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facial_recognition_software) by recording a video of the protester and checking it with the database of criminals maintained by them.[\[495\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Face_Recognition_28_Dec-495) On 14 January, [Supreme Court](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_India) lawyers conducted a protest march from the Supreme Court to Jantar Mantar to protest against the CAA, NRC and NPR.[\[496\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-496) On 19 January, in Delhi, hundreds of protesters joined a protest march holding lighted candles from Jamia University to Shaheen Bagh.[\[272\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-19_Jan_Delhi_candle-272) Some of the protesters had dressed up as [Mahatma Gandhi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi), [BR Ambedkar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/BR_Ambedkar) and other revolutionaries of the [Indian Independence movement](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Independence_movement). A model of detention camp was also paraded in the march.[\[272\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-19_Jan_Delhi_candle-272) #### North East Delhi riots [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=21) Main article: [2020 Delhi riots](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Delhi_riots) Many Cars burnt by Mob in Shiv ViharThe burnt Gym at Shiv Vihar. On 24 February, [violent clashes](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_East_Delhi_riots) occurred at [Jaffrabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaffrabad,_Delhi) and Maujpur in which one police officer and a protester were killed. The pro-CAA demonstrators indulged in stone pelting with the anti-CAA protesters and vandalised houses, vehicles and shops. The police personnel used [tear gas](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tear_gas) and [lathicharge](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lathicharge) against the protestors.[\[497\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-497)[\[498\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-498) Later, it was reported that four protestors also died during the violence.[\[340\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-:4-340) The [Ministry of Home Affairs](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ministry_of_Home_Affairs_(India)) stated that the violence appeared orchestrated because of U.S. President [Donald Trump](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump)'s visit to India.[\[499\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-499) On 26 February, The [United States Commission on International Religious Freedom](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Commission_on_International_Religious_Freedom) (USCIRF) condemned the violence in New Delhi.[\[500\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-500) USCIRF Chair [Tony Perkins](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony_Perkins_(politician)) said, "We urge the Indian government to make serious efforts to protect Muslims and others targeted by mob violence."[\[501\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-501) The Organization of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) has also condemned the New Delhi violence. It stated that steps must be taken to prevent the incidents of " [Islamophobia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islamophobia)" in the country. The OIC statement further went on to add that it "condemns the recent and alarming violence against Muslims in India, resulting in the death and injury of innocent people and the arson and vandalism of mosques and Muslim-owned properties."[\[502\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-502) The Government of India (GOI) has reacted by describing the criticism from the OIC as "inaccurate, selective, and misleading." The GOI also described USCIRF's criticism as "factually inaccurate and misleading, and appear to be aimed at politicising the issue." [\[503\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-503) #### Shaheen Bagh [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=22) Main article: [Shaheen Bagh protest](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaheen_Bagh_protest) Shaheen Bagh on New Year's Eve. Since 14 December, a continuous 24/7 sit in protest is being conducted. The protest began in the afternoon of 14 December with just 15 local women, and went on to gather thousands of protesters with crowds reaching as high as 100,000 on Sundays.[\[504\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-504)[\[505\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-505) On New Year's Eve, thousands of protesters camping at the site sung the [Indian national anthem](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_national_anthem).[\[506\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-506) They were joined in by celebrities and activists on 31 December.[\[507\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-507) But in a turn of events, the protest took a turn for the worst when anti India slogans were shouted at Shaheen Bagh with reference to Jinnah and a call out to try and break India ( _Jinnah wali Azadi_), where many miscreants with their own agenda had joined.[\[508\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-508) The day was also recorded to have been the coldest in Delhi in the past 100 years.[\[509\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-509) On 10 January, the [Delhi High Court](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_High_Court) rejected a plea to shift the Shaheen Bagh protesters.[\[510\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-510) The area has been covered with protest artwork.[\[511\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-511) ### West Bengal [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=23) On Saturday, 14 December 2019, violent protests occurred in West Bengal as the protesters attacked railway stations and public buses. Five trains were set on fire by the protesters in [Lalgola](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lalgola_railway_station) and [Krishnapur railway stations](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Krishnapur_railway_station) in [Murshidabad district](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Murshidabad_district); railway tracks were also damaged in Suti.[\[159\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_14Dec-159) On Monday, 16 December 2019, tens of thousands of people joined a protest march led by Chief Minister [Mamata Banerjee](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mamata_Banerjee) and her ruling [Trinamool Congress](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_India_Trinamool_Congress) party.[\[79\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_Plea-79) Mamata Banerjee stated that the NRC and CAA would not be implemented in West Bengal state as long as she was alive. She appealed people not to resort to violence, while accusing people from outside the state and members of the [BJP](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party) of engaging in arson.[\[512\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-512)[\[513\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-513) On Tuesday, 17 December 2019, protests that included road and rail blockades continued in parts of West Bengal including the districts of [South 24 Parganas](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_24_Parganas), [North 24 Parganas](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_24_Parganas_district) and [Nadia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nadia_district).[\[514\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-514) On 19 December 2019, a crowd with thousands of protesters gathered at Moulali in central Kolkata to peacefully object CAA and NRC.[\[170\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Live_19-170) Mamata Banerjee held a second rally in Kolkata and stated that the Central Government was trying to project the CAA Protests as though it was a Hindu vs Muslim fight.[\[168\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_3_lives-168) She also stated that "BJP is buying skull caps for its cadres who are wearing them while vandalising properties to malign a particular community,".[\[515\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_Kolkata_Rally-515) Earlier, on 18 December, a young [BJP](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/BJP) worker along with five associates, wearing [lungi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lungi) and [skullcap](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taqiyah_(cap)) were seen by the local residents throwing stones on a train engine. The arsonists were caught by the locals who handed them to the [Murshidabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Murshidabad) police.[\[516\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-516)[\[517\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-517)[\[518\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-518) On 21 December 2019, a protest march that the police estimated to be of 10,000 people was held in [Kolkata](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kolkata) from [Shahid Minar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaheed_Minar,_Kolkata) till [Mahajati Sadan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahajati_Sadan).[\[185\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TelegraphFloodgates-185) Between 13 and 17 December 2019, multiple incidents of violence were reported during the protests. According to the police, as of 21 December, more than 600 people had been arrested for allegedly being involved in the violence.[\[182\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_16_Killed-182) On 23 December 2019, Governor [Jagdeep Dhankhar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jagdeep_Dhankhar) was stopped by the students at [Jadavpur University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jadavpur_University), from attending the university convocation ceremony. The vice-president of the BJP West Bengal unit raised questions that why the Muslims were excluded from the amendment if it was not about religion.[\[519\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-519) On 24 December 2019, Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee lead a protest march in Kolkata from [Swami Vivekananda](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swami_Vivekananda) statue at [Bidhan Sarani](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bidhan_Sarani). She accused PM Narendra Modi and Union Home Minister Amit Shah of making contradictory statements. She stated "The prime minister is saying there has been no discussion or proposal on NRC. But a few days ago, BJP president and Union Home Minister Amit Shah had said NRC exercise would be carried out across the country. Both the statements are contradictory. We wonder who is speaking the truth. They are trying to create confusion,".[\[520\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-520) On 3 January, the radical Islamic organisation [Popular Front of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Popular_Front_of_India) (PFI) had planned an anti CAA protest for 5 January, but the West Bengal police denied permission for it.[\[521\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_PFI_3_Jan-521) Since 7 January, women had been conducting a sit in protest at the grounds of Park Circus in Kolkata.[\[239\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Park_Circus_16_Jan-239) On 11 January, PM Modi visited Kolkata on a two-day official visit. Hundreds of people protested against CAA at the Kolkata airport.[\[247\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Rediff_11_Jan-247) Several parties and student unions launched a protest at the Dorina Crossing at Esplanade in Kolkata. SFI leader stated that the protests would continue till Sunday, until PM Modi (who had been visiting the city) was in Kolkata.[\[248\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-News18_11_Jan-248) On 22 January, a 5 kilometre long procession against CAA was led by CM Mamta Bannerjee in [Darjeeling](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Darjeeling), West Bengal. The participants wore ethnic dresses and also played musical instruments. The participants chanted anti CAA slogans and carried banners and posters.[\[287\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-22_Jan_Darjeeling-287) On 26 January (Republic Day), thousands formed parallel 11 km long human chains from [Shyambazar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shyambazar) to Golpark in Kolkata.[\[522\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-522) ### Punjab [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=24) Protests begun in [Malerkotta](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malerkotla), [Patiala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patiala) and [Ludhiana](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ludhiana) with the support of [Khalsa Aid](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Khalsa_Aid), Alliance of Sikh Organisations and various Dalit organisations.[\[523\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-523) By 17 December, protests were being held in [Amritsar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amritsar), Malerkotla, [Machhiwara](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machhiwara), [Bathinda](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bathinda) and [Ludhiana](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ludhiana). Students of [Panjab University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panjab_University), [Punjabi University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punjabi_University) and [Central University of Punjab](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_University_of_Punjab) took a leading role in the protests backed by the Association of Democratic Rights. [Razia Sultana](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Razia_Sultana_(politician)), the only Muslim MLA and a Minister of the [Punjab Cabinet](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_Amarinder_Singh_ministry) organised a large protest in Malerkotla.[\[524\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-524) A cabinet meeting in Punjab decided to proceed as per the decision of the state assembly. A statement was released stating, "The ministers also expressed concern over the implications of the blatantly unconstitutional and divisive CAA, NRC and NPR," They also expressed concern on the violence over CAA stating, the issue "threatened to rip apart the secular fabric of the nation".[\[263\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Wire_Guj_15_Jan-263) ### Uttar Pradesh [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=25) Main article: [CAA protests in Uttar Pradesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/CAA_protests_in_Uttar_Pradesh) Protests were held in [Aligarh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aligarh), [Kanpur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kanpur), [Bareilly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bareilly), [Varanasi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Varanasi) and [Lucknow](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucknow).[\[525\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-525) [Banaras Hindu University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Banaras_Hindu_University) students also protested the police action targeting AMU and Jamia students.[\[526\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-news18_vented-526) However, they also held a rally in support of the CAA and NRC.[\[527\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-527) On 19 December, the administration banned public assembly all over the state to prevent further protests in the state. Access to the internet was restricted in [Azamgarh district](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azamgarh_district) for 2 days, after protest continued for 2 days in the area.[\[170\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Live_19-170) In Lucknow, several buses, cars, media vans and motorbikes were torched. [Uttar Pradesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh) Chief Minister [Yogi Adityanath](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yogi_Adityanath) stated that the authorities would seize the properties of those who indulge in violence in the state.[\[528\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-528) On 20 December 2019, six protesters are killed in police firing in UP.[\[180\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-news18_6_deaths_in_up-180) According to the [Press Trust of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Press_Trust_of_India), the death toll from Friday's protests in Uttar Pradesh's 13 districts has risen to 11.[\[69\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-al_jazeera-69) On 21 December 2019, violent protests along with alleged police brutality were reported from several districts across the state. Access to the internet was restricted. The number of fatalities in the state increased to 16.[\[466\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-News18Cops263-466) Multiple clashes causing injuries to several people were reported. According to the police, 263 policemen were injured, of which 57 were firearm injuries. NDTV later reported that they could only find one policeman with bullet wound and the police did not share the list of 57 policemen with bullet injuries.[\[529\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_4_Jan_bullet-529) Police arrested 705 people in the state, with 102 arrested for making allegedly objectionable remarks or social media posts.[\[530\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-530)[\[466\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-News18Cops263-466) According to the UP Police, as of 21 December, a total of 218 people had been arrested in Lucknow.[\[182\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_16_Killed-182) On 24 December, [Uttar Pradesh Police](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh_Police) stated that 21,500 people were charged in 15 FIRs for violent incidents in Kanpur.[\[531\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-531) In [Muzaffarnagar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muzaffarnagar) the government, sealed 67 shops. Chief Minister, Adityanath had threatened the protesters that his government would auction the properties of the rioters to recover the losses due to the damage made to the property.[\[200\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-News18Muzaffarnagar-200)[\[201\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-SiasatRakshak-201)[\[532\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-532)[\[202\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTVVandalising-202) On 26 December, In Sambhal, UP, the government sent notices to 26 people for their alleged involvement in damaging properties during protests and asked them to explain their position or pay for the loss due to damage of property. The losses to the property were assessed to be [₹](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_rupee)11.66 [lakh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lakh) (US$14,000).[\[204\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Sambhal_Damage-204) Earlier, on 22 December, the UP government had created a panel to assess the damage to the property and to recover the losses by seizing the property of the alleged protesters.[\[191\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Lucknow_22_Dec_IT-191) The social activists accused the government of intimidating the protesters.[\[533\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-533) On 28 December, the _Indian Express_ reported that with 19 killed and 1,246 people arrested based on 372 FIRs lodged in the state, UP was the worst affected state with the biggest police crackdown in India.[\[206\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CAA_Express_live_28_Dec-206) Even though the official figure of number of deaths so far in UP was 19, opposition parties claimed that the actual figure was higher. The UP police had maintained that the deaths of protesters were not the result of police firing, but later on they admitted that some deaths were indeed caused by the police but attributed those incidents to shots fired in self defence.[\[534\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Deaths_5_Jan-534) On 17 January in Lucknow, around 500 women along with their children started a sit in protest at 2 pm near the Clock Tower.[\[270\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TH_19_Jan_blanket-270)(subscription required)[\[535\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-19_Jan_CAA_blanket-535) The police tried to convince them to end the protest but the protesters refused to move. On the night of 18 January, Uttar Pradesh police cracked down on the CAA protesters and snatched their blankets, utensils and food items.[\[271\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-UP_blanket_19_Jan-271) The video of policemen carrying away the blankets was recorded and shared on social media. The conduct of UP police was criticised by the users and the phrase "KAMBALCHOR\_UPPOLICE" (blanket thief UP Police) became the top trend on Twitter in India.[\[271\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-UP_blanket_19_Jan-271) The police responded saying that they had confiscated the blankets following due procedure. The protesters alleged that police also cut the electricity connection to the ground, locked the public toilet nearby and poured water on the bonfire in the winter night.[\[535\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-19_Jan_CAA_blanket-535) The police had issued a prohibition on assembly in Lucknow,[\[535\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-19_Jan_CAA_blanket-535) and stated that they will prosecute the protesters for violating it.[\[270\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TH_19_Jan_blanket-270) On 21 January, police registered cases against 160 women for violation of the ban on assembly and protesting against CAA in Lucknow.[\[281\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-160_booked_21_Jan-281) On 16 December, in response to the police crackdown at Jamia Millia University in Delhi and Aligarh Muslim University over the Citizenship Amendment Act, clashes between the police and protesters occurred in Dakshintola area of [Mau](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mau,_Uttar_Pradesh), Uttar Pradesh. On 17 December, students of [IIT Kanpur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Technology_Kanpur) assembled in a peaceful protest against the CAA and to express solidarity with the students of [Jamia Millia Islamia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Millia_Islamia).[\[536\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-536) ### Karnataka [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=26) On 16 December, protests against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) were held in various parts of [Karnataka](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karnataka). In [Mysore](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mysore), hundreds of protestors marched on the street, raising slogans and took out bike rallies. The police imposed a [ban on public assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Section_144) in Mysore. In [Bangalore](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bangalore), the [IISc](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Science) students organised silent protest in the campus in solidarity with the students of Delhi and other parts of India.[\[526\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-news18_vented-526) In [Shimoga](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shimoga), former [MLA](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minister_of_Legislative_Assembly) [K B Prasanna Kumar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/K._B._Prasanna_Kumar) was leading the protests near Gandhi Park in the city. The police detained him alleging that the protests were turning violent. Protests also occurred in [Bellary](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bellary), [Bidar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bidar), [Gulbarga](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gulbarga), [Kodagu](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kodagu) and [Udupi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Udupi).[\[526\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-news18_vented-526)[\[537\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-minute-537) In [Raichur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raichur) protests were held after the announcement of the CAA, as the protestors had concerns that approximately 5,000 of the 20,000 Bangladeshi immigrants in the [Sindhanur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sindhanur) camp would get Indian citizenship.[\[537\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-minute-537)[\[538\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-538) On 21 January more than 300,000 people join an anti-CAA protest rally at [Kalaburagi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kalaburagi) in Karnataka.[\[277\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Kalburgi_22_Jan-277) The rally was held 13-acre Peer Bangali ground, where people waving national flags had occupied the ground and the nearby roads. [Sitaram Yechury](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sitaram_Yechury), general secretary of [Communist Party of India (Marxist)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communist_Party_of_India_(Marxist)) and [M. Mallikarjun Kharge](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/M._Mallikarjun_Kharge), general secretary of the [All-India Congress Committee](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All-India_Congress_Committee), activists [Swamy Agnivesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swamy_Agnivesh) and former IAS officer Sasikanth Senthil gave speeches in the event. Yechury asked the people to conduct a peaceful civil disobedience movement with aim to defy the CAA, NPR, and NCR to "save the country from Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Home Minister Amit Shah".[\[277\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Kalburgi_22_Jan-277) #### Bangalore [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=27) On 19 December, hundreds of protesters, including historian [Ramachandra Guha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramachandra_Guha), were detained by the [Bangalore Police](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bangalore_Police) from [Town Hall](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bangalore_Town_Hall).[\[539\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-539)[\[540\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-540) On 20 December, Karnataka High Court asked the state government to explain the prohibitions on the assembly in the state.[\[541\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-541) On 23 December, over 100,000 protesters gathered around the town hall in Bangalore.[\[542\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-542) On 4 January in Bangalore hundreds of protesters participated in a rally and accused [Modi government](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modi_government) of attempts to divide India on the basis of religion, and distracting people from the issues of economic slowdown and job losses in the country.[\[235\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Reuters_4_Jan_Hyd-235) Respecting Section 144 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, in force in the city until the midnight of 21 December, around 60 students from the [Indian Institute of Management Bangalore](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Management_Bangalore) came out in turns at the campus gate and left blank placards and their footwear at the campus gate, letting their footwear represent them.[\[543\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-543) As of 14 January 2020, 82 separate protest occasions had taken place in the city. The number was observed to be the highest number of protests in a month in the city's history. The protests were primarily held in Town Hall and [Freedom Park](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freedom_Park,_Bangalore).[\[544\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-544) On 25 January, more than thousand women staged a sit in protest at Frazer Town in Bangalore for 48 hours.[\[299\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-25_January_2020-299) #### Mangalore [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=28) According to _India Today_, on 19 December seven CCTV recorded the arrival of a mob near a Mangalore police station along with a tempo carrying gunny bags full of stones. They then made an organised attempt to attack a police station, block all roads to the station, stone the police personnel and steal firearms.[\[545\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ittodaycctv-545) This was followed by the police firing on the mob, killing two people. The family of the deceased stated that the police used excessive force and should have tried to disperse the crowd instead.[\[545\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ittodaycctv-545) In [Mangalore](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mangalore) 38 protesters from [Campus Front of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Campus_Front_of_India) who were marching towards the [Deputy commissioner](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deputy_commissioner) residence were arrested by the police arrested on charges of blocking traffic on Balmatta Road.[\[546\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Mangaluru-546) On 19 December, a curfew was imposed in Mangalore until 20 December, while protesters marched on the streets defying prohibitory orders. Two people died with gunshot wounds after police fired on the crowd.[\[170\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Live_19-170)[\[175\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ToIMalayali19-175) The police in [riot gear](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riot_gear) then entered the Highland Hospital where the two people with gunshot wounds were brought. The police were accused of beating up patients and their relatives. The incident was caught on [CCTV Cameras](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/CCTV_Cameras), in which the policemen were seen banging on the hospital's [ICU](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intensive_care_unit) doors.[\[177\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto1-177)[\[176\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto2-176) Home Minister of Karnataka [Basavaraj Bommai](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basavaraj_Bommai) accused the people from [Kerala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerala) for the violence in Mangalore.[\[547\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-547) Karnataka Police restricted the entry of people from Kerala to Mangalore at the [Thalappady](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thalappady,_Kasaragod) state border and detained more than 50 people without identity cards.[\[548\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-548) On 20 December, the mobile phones of several journalists in Mangalore (many from Kerala) were confiscated and the journalists were detained.[\[549\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-549)[\[550\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-550)[\[551\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-551) The Chief Minister of Kerala, [Pinarayi Vijayan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinarayi_Vijayan) who condemned the action as an attack on [media freedom](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Media_freedom) and intervened after which the journalists were released.[\[552\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-552) On 22 December, the Karnataka government announced a compensation of [₹](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_rupee)10 [lakh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lakh) (US$12,000) each to the families of the two men killed in violent protests in Mangalore on 19 December.[\[189\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-News18_Kar_10_Lakh-189) The compensation was later withheld and an enquiry was initiated on the killed men.[\[190\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IE_26_Dec_Karnataka-190) On 15 January, more than 200,000 people joined the anti-CAA protests in Mangalore, hundreds of whom came to the venue in boats carrying Indian flags. Activists Harsh Mander and Kannan Gopinathan gave speeches during the protests. An organiser said that they considered the CAA, an anti-constitutional law that will be affecting not just Muslims but all religions. The event ended peacefully with the singing of National anthem.[\[262\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Mangalore_15_Jan-262) ### Tamil Nadu [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=29) On 16 December, protests against CAA were organised by Muslim organisations and political parties in [Tirupathur district](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tirupathur_district) of [Tamil Nadu](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tamil_Nadu). Effigies of Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Home Minister Amit Shah were burnt, after which more than a hundred people were detained by the police.[\[553\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TNIE_Tamil_Nadu-553) Demonstrations protesting against the CAA and the attack on students in Delhi were also held by the students of Government Law College at [Katpadi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katpadi) and Government Arts College in [Tiruvannamalai](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tiruvannamalai).[\[553\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TNIE_Tamil_Nadu-553) On 20 December, actor [Siddharth](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siddharth_(actor)), singer [T. M. Krishna](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/T._M._Krishna) and 600 others were detained for anti-CAA protests in Valluvar Kottam In Chennai.[\[554\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Mathrubhumi_20_dec-554) On 23 December [Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dravida_Munnetra_Kazhagam) along with allied parties held a "mega rally" as an anti-CAA protest in Chennai.[\[555\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-555)[\[556\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-556) Protests were also continued to be held in various parts of Tamil Nadu including [Salem](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salem,_Tamil_Nadu) and [Krishnagiri](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Krishnagiri).[\[557\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-557) In Chennai, eight anti-CAA activists, including five women, were arrested for drawing _[kolams](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kolam)_ criticising the CAA and NRC.[\[558\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TOI-Kolam-2-558) Following their arrest, the opposition DMK officially supported the _kolam_ protest, and anti-CAA and anti-NRC _kolams_ were drawn outside the houses of its leaders and members.[\[559\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TOI-Kolam-1-559) On 16 January, police in [Chennai](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chennai) banned all protests in the city for a period of 15 days. 5 women and 1 man (including a physically disabled person) were detained by the police for protesting against CAA.[\[267\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TNM_Chennai_16_Jan-267) ### Gujarat [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=30) On 16 December, around 50 people protesting outside the [Indian Institute of Management Ahmedabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Management_Ahmedabad) and [CEPT University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/CEPT_University) were detained by the [Gujarat Police](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gujarat_Police).[\[560\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-560)[\[561\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-561) On 17 December, five students were arrested by the [Gujarat police](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gujarat_police) for allegedly creating a [graffiti](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graffiti) against Citizenship Act. According to the police, the students (all in their early twenties) of the [Maharaja Sayajirao University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maharaja_Sayajirao_University)'s Fine Arts department had made a graffiti that said "no CAB Modi", but instead of the letter 'o' in the phrase the students made a ' [swastika](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swastika)' sign. The graffiti was made at locations that included police headquarters, Kala Ghoda Circle, the Fatehgunj pavilion wall and the wall of a hostel near Rosary School. A police complaint was registered on 16 December for "using provocative and humiliating words to hurt sentiments of the people from one community and cause violence, and also damaging public property". The Police alleged that "They used slogans with certain symbols in their graffiti to intentionally hurt religious sentiments of a particular community and affect public peace and cause riots against members of a community. They also damaged public property." The police has already arrested five and two students who were absconding were being searched.[\[464\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_CAA_17_Dec-464) On 19 December 2019, peaceful protest march were carried out in several parts of [Ahmedabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ahmedabad). The peaceful protest march in [Shah-e-Alam's Roza](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shah-e-Alam%27s_Roza) area turned violent after police intervened to disperse the crowd. Police used tear gas to counter [stone pelting](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stone_pelting) while trying to disperse a crowd of 2000 protesters.[\[178\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_Gujarat_19-178) Protest rallies and strikes were also organised in several cities of Gujarat.[\[562\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-562) On 19 December 2019, videos surfaced allegedly showing protestors attacking policemen in Ahmedabad and Banaskantha.[\[563\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-563)[\[564\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-564) On 25 December 2019, many activists alleged that [Nirma University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nirma_University) in Ahmedabad tried to "intimidate" its students who took part in protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act and also advised their parents to "counsel" them. The SMS sent by the university to the protesting students' parents read thus: " It has come to our knowledge that your ward was involved in protest against recent issues. The Police and Intelligence Bureau-IB have taken details of your ward from us... This is also to inform you that if your ward continues to participate in the protest, the police might create a record against him."[\[565\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-565) On 15 January 2020, a petition was filed in Gujarat High Court asking for the court's intervention to allow the petitioners to hold Anti-CAA protests in Ahmedabad. The petitioners stated that police did not grant them permission for peaceful anti-CAA protests but granted permission to 62 programmes held by the BJP to support the CAA. The petitioners said that the administration keeps denying the permission to Anti-CAA protesters and called it a violation of fundamental rights of the citizens. The Court asked the police to decide timely on the protests application.[\[263\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Wire_Guj_15_Jan-263) ### Kerala [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=31) See also: [Human chain in Kerala, 2020](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_chain_in_Kerala,_2020) Protests at [Ernakulam](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernakulam), c. 23 December 2019. On 16 December, the ruling coalition, the [Left Democratic Front (LDF)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Left_Democratic_Front_(Kerala)), and the opposition coalition, the [United Democratric Front (UDF)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Democratic_Front_(Kerala)), organised a joint [hunger strike](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hunger_strike) in the [Thiruvananthapuram](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thiruvananthapuram) Martyr's Square. Chief Minister [Pinarayi Vijayan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinarayi_Vijayan) stated that Kerala will "stand together to fight against the evil designs of the Modi government undermining the secular credentials of India", terming the Citizens Amendment Act "anti-constitutional and anti-people". Leader of the Opposition [Ramesh Chennithala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramesh_Chennithala) observed that another struggle for Independence is required to save the constitution from " [fascist](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fascist) forces".[\[566\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-India_Today_Kerala-566) On 17 December, A dawn-to-dusk hartal (shutdown) was observed in Kerala by [Welfare Party of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Welfare_Party_of_India), [Bahujan Samaj Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bahujan_Samaj_Party), [Social Democratic Party of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_of_India) and other 30 organisation against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act and the police violence against students at various universities across the country, in relation to anti-CAA protests.[\[165\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ITStoned-165)[\[166\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TimesNowKeralaHartal-166) The Kerala police detained 233 people in connection with the hartal, including 55 people in Ernakulam, 51 in Thrissur and 35 in Idukki. In Palakkad 21 people have been detained, while 13 were detained in Kannur, 12 in Kottayam and 8 in Wayanad.[\[567\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-567) On 23 December, multiple protests in Kochi was organised and took place.[\[568\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-568) People's long march, which started from [Jawaharlal Nehru Stadium](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru_Stadium_(Kochi)) premises and ended near [Cochin Shipyard](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cochin_Shipyard). Cultural activists led another march from the Gandhi Square to Vasco De Gama Square at [Fort Kochi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Kochi).[\[569\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-569) Another march led by CPI state secretary [Kanam Rajendran](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kanam_Rajendran) was also held at the same time started from [Kalamassery](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kalamassery) and ended in Rajendra Maidanam.[\[570\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-570)[\[571\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-571) On 24 December, [Differently-abled](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disability) Come together against CAA and NRC at [Marine Drive, Kochi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marine_Drive,_Kochi).[\[572\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-572) On 28 December, several delegates attending the [Indian History Congress](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_History_Congress) held at [Kannur University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kannur_University) protested during Kerala Governor [Arif Mohammad Khan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arif_Mohammad_Khan)'s speech. Some of them were detained by police, but were later released following an intervention by Kannur University.[\[573\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Kannur_Unv_protest-573) On 31 December, [Kerala Legislative Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerala_Legislative_Assembly) passed a resolution demanding scrapping of the Act.[\[574\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-574) On 1 January 2020 in [Kochi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kochi), around half a million assembled in peaceful rally to protest against the CAA-NRC, held between [Jawaharlal Nehru Stadium](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru_Stadium,_Kochi) and [Marine Drive](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marine_Drive,_Kochi).[\[575\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-575)[\[576\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-576) On 14 January, the [Kerala government](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerala_government) approached Supreme Court to challenge the CAA under section 131 of the constitution and becomes the first state to do so. The article 131 of the Indian constitution provides Supreme Court the power to decide the disputes between the states and the Government of India.[\[257\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Kerala_CAA_14_Jan-257)[\[258\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-14_Jan-258) The Kerala government in its petition called the act "a violation of India's secular constitution" and accused the Indian government of dividing the country among religious lines. Kerala Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan said, "Kerala will always remain in the forefront of this fight to protect the Indian constitution and the fundamental rights of its citizens,". Vijayan added that Kerala will save the rights of the citizens from the unconstitutional CAA by fighting against it using constitutional methods.[\[577\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-aljazeera_14_Jan-577) On 26 January, to protest against the CAA and the proposed NRC the [Left Democratic Front](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Left_Democratic_Front_(Kerala)) led by the Communist Party of India (Marxist) had organised the human chain. The chain was formed by approximately 6 to 7 million people and extended for a distance of 620 kilometres from [Kasaragod](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kasaragod_district) to [Kaliyikkavila](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kaliyakkavilai).[\[578\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-578)[\[304\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-:1-304) ### Telangana [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=32) Million March, Hyderabad On 16 December, thousands of students from major institutes in [Hyderabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyderabad) such as [University of Hyderabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Hyderabad), [Osmania University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osmania_University) and [MANU University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maulana_Azad_National_Urdu_University) participated in protests, demanding a rollback of the CAA.[\[579\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-579) On 21 December, numerous protests took place across Hyderabad organised by students, NGOs and various political parties. The [Hyderabad Police](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyderabad_Police) stated that the protests remained peaceful. Protesters demanded Chief Minister [K. Chandrashekar Rao](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/K._Chandrashekar_Rao), whose party [Telangana Rashtra Samithi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telangana_Rashtra_Samithi) had voted against the bill in parliament, to end his silence with respect to the CAA.[\[580\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-580) By 23 December, it was reported that protests had spread to smaller towns, including Nizamabad.[\[581\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-581) On 4 January, more than 100,000 protesters attended the protest march named "Million March" in Hyderabad.[\[235\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Reuters_4_Jan_Hyd-235) The protesters displayed placards with slogans saying "Withdraw CAA immediately," and "India's only religion in secularism".[\[235\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Reuters_4_Jan_Hyd-235) ### Bihar [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=33) On 17 December, posters describing Bihar Chief Minister [Nitish Kumar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nitish_Kumar) as "missing" were erected as a form of protest in Patna. Nitish Kumar had been criticised for his silence over the CAA. while his party, [Janata Dal (United)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Janata_Dal_(United)), had supported the bill in both the Houses of Parliament as part of the alliance with the [Bharatiya Janata Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party). The JD(U) party strategist [Prashant Kishor](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prashant_Kishor), party spokesperson [Pavan Verma](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pavan_Varma) and MLC [Gulam Rasool Balyawi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gulam_Rasool_Balyawi) had voiced dissatisfaction over the party's stance on CAA.[\[582\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-582)[\[583\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-583) On 19 December, Nitish Kumar declared that the NRC will not be implemented in the state, becoming the first major [Bharatiya Janata Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party) ally to reject the controversial measure.[\[584\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-584) On 19 December, a [bandh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bandh) was called by [communist](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communism) parties in [Bihar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bihar), supported by a number of small parties, where protesters blocked rail and road traffic in protest against CAA and the proposed countrywide implementation of NRC.[\[585\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-585)[\[425\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-HBL-425) On Saturday, 21 December, a "Bihar bandh" was called by the [Rashtriya Janata Dal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rashtriya_Janata_Dal) (RJD), where bandh supporters reportedly blocked railway tracks in [Araria](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Araria_district) and [East Champaran](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Champaran_district) districts. In [Nawada](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nawada), bandh supporters demonstrated on [National Highway 31](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Highway_31_(India)) where wheels were burned on the road and the movement of vehicles was disrupted, while in [Vaishali](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vaishali_district), the highway was blocked with the help of buffaloes. In Patna, hundreds of party supporters with lathis entered the railway stations and bus stations with party flags, but were repulsed by policemen. At [Darbhanga](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Darbhanga), RJD workers and supporters protested bare chest, sloganeering against Bihar chief minister Nitish Kumar and central government.[\[586\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-586)[\[587\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-587) During a protest at [Phulwari Sharif](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phulwari_Sharif) near Patna, some of the miscreants started pelting stones and a clash broke out between protesters and the supporters of the Act. A nearby temple and a cemetery were damaged in the clash. Eyewitnesses said police had used tear gas and water cannon to disperse the people. Police said that people of Hindu community fired bullets that injured nine Muslim men.[\[588\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-588) During the stampede, an eighteen years old teenage protester Amir Hanzla ran towards the lanes of Sangat Mohalla, a neighbourhood that was a hub of [RSS-affiliated](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/RSS-affiliated) right wing Hindutva members.[\[589\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-589) His dead body was found a week after he was allegedly murdered by the [Hindutva](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindutva) extremists.[\[590\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-590) Police arrested six people accused in the case who belonged to Hindu Putra Sangathan, a Hindutva group. All of the suspects confessed their crimes and police is also investigating 18 other organisations related to this extremist group.[\[591\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-591) ### Maharashtra [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=34) On 19 December, different NGOs and college students, backed by [Congress](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_National_Congress), [Nationalist Congress Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nationalist_Congress_Party) and [Left Democratic Front](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Left_Democratic_Front_(Maharashtra)) parties, jointly formed a front with the name " _Hum Bharat Ke Log_" and held a protest at the August Kranti Maidan.[\[592\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-592)[\[170\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Live_19-170) In Mumbai, several actors including [Farhan Akhtar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Farhan_Akhtar), [Swara Bhaskar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swara_Bhaskar), [Huma Qureshi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huma_Qureshi), [Raj Babbar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raj_Babbar), [Sushant Singh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sushant_Singh), [Javed Jaffrey](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Javed_Jaffrey), [Aditi Rao Hydari](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aditi_Rao_Hydari), [Parvathy Thiruvothu](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parvathy_Thiruvothu), [Konkona Sen Sharma](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Konkona_Sen_Sharma), [Nandita Das](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nandita_Das), [Arjun Mathur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arjun_Mathur) and filmmakers [Anurag Kashyap](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anurag_Kashyap), [Rakeysh Omprakash Mehra](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rakeysh_Omprakash_Mehra), and [Saeed Mirza](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saeed_Mirza) joined in the protest venue.[\[168\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_3_lives-168)[\[593\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Celebrities_Express-593)[\[594\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ET_B_Town-594) Mumbai police had deployed more than 2,500 policemen to monitor and control around 20,000 protesters.[\[179\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Mumbai_Mirror_19-179) The peaceful protest concluded without any violent incidents. Mumbai police was praised by prominent artists including [Farhan Akhtar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Farhan_Akhtar), [Swara Bhaskar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swara_Bhaskar), [Kunal Kamra](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kunal_Kamra), politician [Milind Deora](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milind_Deora) and citizens for its professional conduct in maintaining law and order.[\[595\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-The_Hindu_Mumbai_19-595) Protests were held in other cities in the state such as [Pune](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pune), [Nashik](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nashik), [Malegaon](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malegaon), [Kolhapur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kolhapur) and [Nagpur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nagpur).[\[596\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-596)[\[597\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-597) On 28 December, on the occasion of the foundation day of the party, the state unit of the Congress party in Mumbai undertook a flag march and used the slogan "Save Bharat-Save Constitution". The march started from the August Kranti Maidan and ended at the statue of [Lokmanya Tilak](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lokmanya_Tilak) near Girgaum Chowpatty. It was attended by office bearers and workers of the party.[\[206\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CAA_Express_live_28_Dec-206) Similar marches were held in many parts of the country.[\[207\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Congress_28_Dec_N18-207) On the midnight of 6 January, students of [IIT Bombay](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/IIT,_Bombay) began a protest called "Occupy [Gateway](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gateway_of_India)" in Mumbai in response to the [attack on Jawaharlal Nehru University campus](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_JNU_Attack). They were joined in by hundreds of protesters, including activists [Feroze Mithiborwala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feroze_Mithiborwala), [Umar Khalid](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Umar_Khalid) and comedian Kunal Kamra.[\[598\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-598)[\[599\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-599) On 12 January, thousands of people joined the anti-CAA protests at Jogeshwari in Mumbai. Slogans such as "I Am From Gujarat, My Documents Burned in 2002", "No CAA, Boycott NRC, Stop Dividing India, Don't Divide us", "Save Constitution", were displayed on the banners. Large number of policemen were also deputed for security.[\[254\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CAA_live_13_Jan-254) Inspired by the Shaheen Bagh protest, a massive anti-CAA-NRC-NPR protest started in Mumbai on 17 January. Around 10,000 women gathered at the YMCA Ground in Mumbai to protest in the evening. The protest was organised by a NGO named Mumbai Citizen Quorum.[\[268\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Shaheen_Mumbai-268) A statewide shutdown, "Maharashtra Bandh" was organised by Vanchit Bahujan Aghadi (VBA) along with 35 other organisations across [Maharashtra](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maharashtra) state, to protest against CAA and the economic policies of the BJP-led central government, which according to the organisers "were ruining the country". The activists of VBA forced shopkeepers to shut down their stores. A bus was damaged due to stone pelting.[\[294\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-N18_24_January_2020-294)[\[295\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-HT_24_Jan_Maha_Bandh-295) On 6 January, 50,000 women held an "all women's rally" in [Malegaon](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malegaon) to protest against the CAA, NRC and NPR. The rally was organised by Dastoor Bachao Committee and Shan-e-Hind, an affiliate of [Janata Dal (Secular)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Janata_Dal_(Secular)).[\[238\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-:2-238) On 1 February, thousands gathered for the [pride parade](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pride_parade), [Queer Azaadi Mumbai](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queer_Azaadi_Mumbai) at [August Kranti Maidan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/August_Kranti_Maidan) which joined in slogans against the CAA and NRC.[\[600\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-600) #### Pune [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=35) Shaheen Bagh protests against CAA, NRC and NPR in Pune on 22 Jan 2020 On 11 January, an all women sit in protest was started outside Konark Mall in Kondhwa, in [Pune](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pune), organised by Kul Jamaat-e-Tanzeem, an umbrella body of several organisations. the protests started with fewer people participating but the crowd grew steadily and reached around 500–600 protesters as reported on 19 January. According to a protester the movement was to save the constitution and the country. Candle light vigil, human chains and speeches were made as part of the protest. The venue had banners with slogans such as 'Tumhari Lathi Se Tej Hamari Awaaz Hai' and 'Liar Liar Desh on Fire', as well as 'India Needs Education, Jobs, Not CAA, NRC, NPR'.[\[274\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-19_Jan_Pune_Shaheen-274) [Shaheen Bagh-style protests](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaheen_Bagh_protests) against CAA, NPR and NRC were held over several days in [Pune Camp](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pune_Camp).[\[601\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-601) #### Nagpur [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=36) In Nagpur, on 24 January, lawyers, doctors and professors conducted a rally. In the rally a high court judge, Ravi Shakar Bhure said that the judiciary had become helpless as well and termed the actions of the government to be part of a massive conspiracy.[\[602\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-602) ### Northeast India [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=37) The Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) implementation has faced significant opposition in Northeast India, especially in Assam. Critics argue the CAA is discriminatory and undermines indigenous rights . The central government's decision to exclude most tribal areas from the CAA has been met with mixed reactions, as regions like Assam still largely fall outside the Sixth Schedule and are thus not exempted .[\[603\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-603) Assam, due to its porous borders with Bangladesh, has been particularly affected by illegal immigration, which heightens the controversy surrounding the CAA . Existing student bodies, such as the Northeast Student Union (NESU), have been criticized for their inaction on the issue . In response, the Wesean Student Federation (WSF) was formed in March 2024, advocating for international intervention and urging the United Nations to address the CAA's discriminatory aspects .[\[604\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-604)[\[605\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-605) Calls for excluding the entire Northeast from the CAA's purview have been persistent, reflecting widespread regional discontent . In Assam, only areas under the Sixth Schedule, like the Bodoland Territorial Region, are exempt, leaving much of the state vulnerable to the CAA . This discrepancy has sparked questions about the state's policy consistency, as highlighted by All Assam Students Union Chief Advisor Samujjal Bhattacharya .[\[606\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-606) Efforts to grant Scheduled Tribe status to additional Assamese communities could potentially lead to a tribal-majority state fully exempt from the CAA, though this has not yet materialized . Meanwhile, organizations like the Asom Jatiyatabadi Yuba Chatra Parishad (AJYCP) are pushing for the implementation of an [Inner Line Permit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inner_Line_Permit) system to further protect against illegal immigration .[\[607\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-607) ### Other states and union territories [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=38) - **Meghalaya:** On 9 December, large scale protests were held in the state. Vehicles and buildings were vandalised in [Shillong](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shillong). Curfew and internet restrictions were imposed in several parts of the state.[\[608\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-608) On 20 December, the internet restrictions were lifted after an order from [Guwahati High Court](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guwahati_High_Court) while night curfews remained in place.[\[609\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-609) The agitations continued in the state with the capital of Shillong being primarily affected. The agitations were led by student organisations with regular demonstrations taking place in universities like North East Hill University.[\[610\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-610) - **Goa**: On 13 December, [Goa Forward Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goa_Forward_Party) chief, [Vijai Sardesai](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vijai_Sardesai), who dubbed the bill as "communal ammunition bill", took part in the protests in [Margao](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Margao).[\[611\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-611) On 22 February, over 15,000 people gathered at a protest in the capital city [Panaji](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panaji), organised by the "Goa Alliance Against CAA-NRC-NPR" with support from the Goa Church.[\[612\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-612) - **Chhattisgarh:** On 15 December, a protest march was held under the banner of the "Anti-CAB Agitation Forum" from Marine Drive area to Ambedkar Chowk in Raipur in the evening.[\[613\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-613) - **Odisha:** On 16 December, thousands of protesters, including farmer leaders, student activists, [Dalit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dalit) leaders and people with disability, hit the road in Odisha against the CAA, NRC and the attack on Jamia students. They marched from Satyanagar Mosque towards the residence of Chief Minister [Naveen Patnaik](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naveen_Patnaik) in [Bhubaneswar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhubaneswar). They also submitted a memorandum to the Chief Minister and Governor [Ganeshi Lal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ganeshi_Lal).[\[614\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-614)[\[615\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-615) On 30 January, 25,000 protesters marched through central Bhubaneswar to protest against the CAA.[\[616\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-616) - **Uttarakhand:** On 16 December, protest marches were organised in [Dehradun](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dehradun_district), [Kashipur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kashipur,_Uttarakhand), [Haridwar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haridwar_district), [Nainital](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nainital_district) and [Udham Singh Nagar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Udham_Singh_Nagar_district), [Haldwani](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haldwani), districts opposing the law terming it discriminatory and unconstitutional.[\[617\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-617)[\[618\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-618) - **Chandigarh:** On 19 December, over 700 students from Punjab University accompanied by students, activists and residents of surrounding districts like [Ambala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ambala_district) and [Patiala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patiala_district) conducted a protest march in city.[\[619\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-619) - **Manipur:** On 19 December, women vendors of [Ima Market](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ima_Market) held a silent protest by closing down all their shops. Students also held protest rallies where a few minor scuffles broke out between them and security forces.[\[620\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-620) - **Madhya Pradesh:** On 20 December, protests reportedly turned violent in [Jabalpur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jabalpur), leading to a curfew being imposed in four police station limits.[\[621\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-FPJ_21_Dec-621) - **Rajasthan:** On 22 December, Chief Minister [Ashok Gehlot](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ashok_Gehlot) led a protest march of nearly 300,000 people christened " _[Samvidhan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constitution_of_India) Bachao rally_" against CAA. The protestors stated that CAA was against the constitution and is an attempt to divide the people based on their religion. They demanded that the new law be repealed. The protest march was supported by several political parties including Congress, [Aam Aadmi Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aam_Aadmi_Party), [Rashtriya Lok Dal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rashtriya_Lok_Dal) and [Janata Dal (Secular)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Janata_Dal_(Secular)).[\[188\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ITRajasthan-188)[\[622\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-622) On 24 December 200,000 people attended a protest in [Kota](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kota,_Rajasthan).[\[623\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-623) On 25 January, Rajasthan Assembly, with Congress in the majority, passed a resolution asking the central government to repeal CAA and also objected against the NPR and NRC.[\[359\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Rajasthan_Assembly-359) ### Overseas [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=39) Protest at the [Mahatma Gandhi Memorial](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi_Memorial_(Washington,_D.C.)) in [Washington D.C.](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington,_D.C.), c. 19 December 2019. Various cities around the world, including New York City, [Washington D. C](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington,_D.C.).,[\[624\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-HinduWashington-624) Paris, Berlin,[\[625\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-QuintBerlin-625) [Geneva](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geneva), Barcelona, San Francisco, Tokyo, [Helsinki](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helsinki),[\[626\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-626) and [Amsterdam](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam), witnessed protests against the Act and the police brutality faced by Indian protesters.[\[627\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-world_protest-627)[\[628\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-628) **North America** Protests were held in solidarity with Indian protesters outside the [Mahatma Gandhi Memorial](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi_Memorial_(Washington,_D.C.)) in [Washington D. C](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington,_D.C.).[\[624\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-HinduWashington-624) Protests were also held at [Harvard University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harvard_University)[\[629\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Harvard-629) and [Massachusetts Institute of Islamia.[\[149\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-quint_CAA-149) Around 100 students and faculty members of [Columbia against the students.[\[627\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-world_protest-627) On 19 December, around 400 present students along with former students of [Harvard University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harvard_University), [Columbia University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Columbia_University), [Yale University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yale_University), [Stanford University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanford_University), [Brown University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brown_University), [Johns Hopkins University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johns_Hopkins_University), [Cornell University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cornell_University), [Carnegie Mellon University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University), [Purdue brutality.[\[630\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-630) On 26 January 2020, the 71st Republic Day of India, protest held in 30 cities of the United States including cities which have Indian consulates like, New York, Chicago, Houston, Atlanta and San Francisco and in front of the Indian Embassy in Washington DC. Various organisations including Indian American Muslim Council (IAMC), Equality Labs, Black Lives Matter (BLM), Jewish Voice for Peace (JVP) and Hindus for Human Rights (HfHR) participated in the protest.[\[631\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-631) **Europe** The first anti-CAA protests in Europe were held outside the [High Commission of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/India_House,_London) in London,[\[632\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-632) on 14 December 2019. On 16 December, students at [University of Edinburgh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Edinburgh) in the United Kingdom demonstrated their protest against the Act.[\[633\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-overseas_varsity_protest_1-633) The university and College Union, Edinburgh had released a statement in solidarity condemning the brutal inflictions exercised by state police on the students of various universities in the country who were protesting against the Act.[\[634\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-634) On 20 December 2019, students from various universities in the [Netherlands](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netherlands) protested against the Act and the [National Register of Citizens](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens_for_Assam) in front of the Indian Embassy at [The Hague](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Hague). Around 300 students from [University of Leiden](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Leiden), [University of Groningen](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Groningen), and [Erasmus University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erasmus_University) assembled in a peaceful protest by reading the [Preamble to the Constitution of slogans.[\[633\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-overseas_varsity_protest_1-633) Till date, four protests were held in front of the embassy by the Indian diaspora living in the Netherlands.[\[635\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-635) Protests were also held in [Berlin](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin), Germany[\[625\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-QuintBerlin-625) and
