embassy.[\[636\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-636)[\[637\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-637) On 21 December 2019, around a hundred students and professionals of Indian origin living in [Munich](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Munich), Germany gathered at the memorial to the [White Rose](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_Rose) Movement outside the [Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ludwig_Maximilian_University_of_Munich) (LMU) and protested against the CAA, NRC, and the police action against the students of [Jamia Millia Islamia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Millia_Islamia) and [Aligarh Muslim University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aligarh_Muslim_University).[\[638\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-638)\[ _[non-primary source needed](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research#Primary,_secondary_and_tertiary_sources)_\]\[ _[better source needed](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS)_\] Diverse voices from France too, joined in for anti-CAA, anti-NRC protests. A letter of solidarity with protests in India and condemning the citizenship legislation, signed by hundreds of students and other professionals including eminent writers like [Shumona Sinha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shumona_Sinha), [Amit Chaudhuri](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amit_Chaudhuri), musicians- [Jean-Philippe Rykiel](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean-Philippe_Rykiel), Prabhu Edouard et al. preceded a planned mass protest gathering.[\[639\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-639) On 4 January 2020, peaceful and song-filled protests by students, educationists and others from the Indian and foreign diaspora were held at Parvis du [Trocadéro](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trocad%C3%A9ro,_Paris) in Paris and also in front of the Indian Embassy, Paris despite facing the irk of some local [BJP](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/BJP) supporters.[\[640\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-640)[\[641\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-641) On 14 January, more than 500 people gathered outside the Indian embassy in London to protest against the CAA.[\[642\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_barriers_16_Jan-642) In [Berlin](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin), Germany more than 200 people join the protest march against CAA, NRC, [JNU attack](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_JNU_attack) on 19 January. The march was led by the Indian diaspora and started at the Brandenburg Gate and ended at the Indian Embassy.[\[273\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Germany_19_Jan-273) On 20 January, several Labour MPs of the UK parliament discussed the concerns on the CAA, in a meeting organised by South Asia Solidarity Group (SASG) and Ambedkar International Mission (UK) in London.[\[275\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Labour_MP_21_Jan-275) The MPs expressed concern on its implications on human rights and disenfranchisement of Muslims.[\[276\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-newsclick_labour_UK-276) On 25 January, in London, around 2000 of people from the Indian diaspora and the Human Rights organisation, conducted a protest march against CAA from the Downing street to the Indian High Commission.[\[297\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-26_Jan_2K_London-297) The protesters demanded the repeal of the CAA stating that it impacts the secular constitution of India. The protesters carried banners with slogans such as "Protect the Constitution", "Stop Dividing India", "United Against Racism in India" and "No Citizenship on the Basis of Religion". The protester also asked for the abolishing the NPR and NRC which could be used along with the CAA for a mass disenfranchisement of Muslims in India.[\[298\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-26_Jan-298) During the march, MP [Sam Tarry](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sam_Tarry), from the UK Opposition Labour Party while addressing the crowd, stated "We are not here as any anti-India demonstration, we are here as a pro-India demonstration. It is incredibly important that our voices are heard against laws that are not good for the future of the country," he added that the human rights in any country is an international issue. Labour MPs [Stephen Timms](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephen_Timms), [Clive Lewis](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clive_Lewis_(politician)) and [Nadia Whittome](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nadia_Whittome) supported the protest with written messages and asked the UK government to discuss it with the Indian government. Some of the groups backing the march were Indian Workers Association (GB), School of Oriental and African Studies (SOAS) India Society, CasteWatch UK, Tamil People in the UK, Indian Muslim Federation(UK), Federation of Redbridge Muslim Organisations (FORMO), Kashmir Solidarity Movement, South Asian Students Against Fascism.[\[298\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-26_Jan-298) A five-page resolution against the CAA was drafted by more than 150 members of the European Union, who stated that it "marks a dangerous shift in the way citizenship will be determined in India and is set to create the largest statelessness crisis in the world and cause immense human suffering".[\[363\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Statelessness_Crisis-363) The members pointed out that the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights has called the CAA 'fundamentally discriminatory', and also accused the Indian government of "discriminating against, harassing and prosecuting national and religious minorities and silencing any opposition, human rights groups... and journalists critical of the government". The members have asked EU to include a "strong human rights clause with an effective implementation and suspension mechanism" while negotiating any trade agreement with India.[\[363\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Statelessness_Crisis-363) **Asia and Oceania** Several silent protests were held in December by students in Israel.[\[643\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-643)\[ _[non-primary source needed](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research#Primary,_secondary_and_tertiary_sources)_\] On the same day,\[ _[clarification needed](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify)_\] students of [University of Dhaka](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Dhaka) assembled in solidarity for the student protesters who were beaten by police and also condemned the CAA.[\[644\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-644) On 22 December, members of the [Indian community in Australia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Australians) gathered at the [Parliament of Victoria](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parliament_of_Victoria) in [Melbourne](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melbourne) in huge numbers and protested against the new Act and police brutality through sloganeering.[\[645\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-645)[\[646\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-646) On 24 December, a 32-year-old Indian national protested against the CAA in the district of [Marina Bay](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marina_Bay,_Singapore) in Singapore. The local authorities called it an unauthorised protest on foreign politics.[\[647\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-647) **Africa** Protests were held outside the Indian Consulate in [Cape Town](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cape_Town).[\[648\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-648)[\[649\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-649) ## Methods [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=40) The protesters used various methods including [demonstrations](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demonstration_(political)), [civil disobedience](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civil_disobedience), _[Dharna](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dharna)_, _[Gherao](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gherao)_, [hunger strikes](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hunger_strikes), _[Satyagraha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satyagraha)_, _[Hartal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hartal)_, [vandalism](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vandalism), _[arsons](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arsons)_, [stone pelting](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stone_pelting), [hashtag activism](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hashtag_activism), [general strike](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_strike) and _[Bandh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bandh)_ against the bill. Protesters used several slogans and poems during the protests. Lyricist and Urdu poet [Rahat Indori](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rahat_Indori)'s famous _[ghazal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ghazal)_ _"Sabhi ka khoon hai shaamil yahan ki mitti mein; kisi ke baap ka Hindustan thodi hai"_ (This land has seen sacrifices from everyone; Hindustan is not anyone's property) resonates throughout the protest.[\[650\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-650) Revolutionary poems by [Pash](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pash) like _"Main Ghas Hoon; Main aapke Kiye Dhare Par Ugh Ayunga"_ (I am grass, I will rise everywhere),[\[651\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-651) lyricist and writer [Varun Grover](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Varun_Grover_(writer))'s poem like _"Tanashah aakar jayenge, hum kagaz nahi dikhayenge"_ (Dictators will come and go but we will not show our documents),[\[652\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Kagaz_by_V.Grover-652)[\[653\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-653) _"Main Inkaar Karta Hoon"_ (I refuse) penned by singer Aamir Aziz[\[654\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-654) and the popular poem _"Main Hindustani Musalmaan Hoon"_ (I am an Indian Muslim) by Indian spoken word poet [Hussain Haidry](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hussain_Haidry) has been used during the protests.[\[655\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-655) Along with poems, the famous revolutionary _"Aazadi!"_ slogan by JNU students has been used extensively throughout the protest in all over the country and abroad.[\[656\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-656)[\[657\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-657)[\[658\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-658) Slogans, poems and songs used during [Indian independence movement](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_independence_movement) like _"Inquilab Zindabad"_ (Long live the revolution) coined by Indian freedom fighter [Hasrat Mohani](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hasrat_Mohani), _" [Sarfaroshi Ki Tamanna](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarfaroshi_Ki_Tamanna) aab haamare dill mein hai; Dekhna hai zor kitna baazu-e-qatil mein hai"_ (The desire for revolution is in our hearts; Let's see how much strength the enemy has) written by [Bismil Azimabadi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bismil_Azimabadi) which were later popularised by martyr [Bhagat Singh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhagat_Singh), [Ashfaqullah Khan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ashfaqullah_Khan), [Chandrashekhar Azad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chandrashekhar_Azad) and [Ram Prasad Bismil](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ram_Prasad_Bismil) were used as main vocal resistance during the protest.[\[659\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-659)[\[660\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-660) Protesters used the poetry written by revolutionary poets such as [Faiz Ahmad Faiz](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Faiz_Ahmad_Faiz) and [Habib Jalib](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Habib_Jalib), both considered symbols of resistance against military dictatorships and state oppression in Pakistan. Poems such as _" [Hum Dekhenge](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hum_Dekhenge)"_ (We will witness) penned by Faiz and _"Main nahin janta, main nahin manta"_ (I refuse to acknowledge, I refuse to accept) penned by Jalib inspired large scale protests in form of banners and recitations. _" [Saare Jahan Se Achcha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saare_Jahan_Se_Achcha) Hindustan Haamara"_ (Better than the entire world, is our Hindustan) by Urdu poet [Muhammad Iqbal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muhammad_Iqbal) was recited in the protests.[\[661\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-661) Singer and lyricist Aamir Aziz wrote _Main Inkaar Karta Hoon_ as a Hindustani protest poem. Aziz's work was [political poetry](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_poetry) which was used during the protests and also to protest against the police brutality on the student protesters who were demonstrating against the Act.[\[662\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-662)[\[663\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-663)[\[664\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-664)[\[665\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-665) Along with Hindi and Urdu literature, English poems and slogans were also used for the protests. Among those one such [dramatic monologue](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dramatic_monologue) by a teacher named Ajmal Khan, "Write me down!, I am an Indian; This is my land, If I have born here, I will die here; There for, Write it down! Clearly In bold and capital letters, On the top of your NRC, that I am an Indian!",[\[666\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-666) improvised from [Mahmoud Darwish](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahmoud_Darwish)'s song [Write Down!](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahmoud_Darwish#2016_poem_controversy), questions the Act's secularism and the Government. The poem strongly urged not to question the identity and patroitism of the Indian Muslims, the tribals, the poor, the landless, the Dalits and questioned the various actions of [right wing organisations](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Right-wing_politics) in the country.[\[667\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-667) [Pink Floyd](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pink_Floyd) co-founder and musician [Roger Waters](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roger_Waters) recites "Everything will be remembered, Everything recorded", an English Transliteration of Aamir Aziz's poem _"Sab Yaad Rakha Jayega"_ at a protest in London.[\[668\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-668) [Kannada](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kannada_literature) poem were also recited to protest. Siraj Bisaralli, a Kannada poet, recited his own poem _"Ninna Dakhale Yaavaga Needuttee?"_ (When will you show your documents?) at a cultural festival and got arrested.[\[669\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-669)[\[670\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-670) English placards like " [Modi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Narendra_Modi)- [Shah](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amit_Shah), You Gave Me Depression", "Rise Against Fascism", "Don't Be Dead Inside For Democracy", "Fascism, Down Down", "I'll show you my documents, if you show your degree!" were used against the CAA-NRC and the Government, and placards like "Delhi Police: Shanti (Peace), Sewa (Service), Nyaya (Justice)?" and "Make Tea Not War" questions the Delhi Police's brutal actions against student protesters.[\[671\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-671) ### Art [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=41) No NPR CAA NRC graffiti on a public toilet at Shaheen Bagh protests, New Delhi, 8 January 2020 Various artists created comics, illustrations, and posters against the CAA and NRC.[\[672\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-672)[\[673\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-673) Several [political cartoonists](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Editorial_cartoonist) created pieces covering the protests.[\[674\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-674) A group of activists in Chennai drew _[kolams](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kolam)_ (geometrical patterns drawn on the ground with rice flour or chalk) criticising the CAA and NRC.[\[559\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TOI-Kolam-1-559)[\[558\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TOI-Kolam-2-558) This novel protest was then officially supported by the opposition DMK party.[\[559\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TOI-Kolam-1-559) Following the _kolam_ protests in Tamil Nadu, anti-CAA protestors in West Bengal also started drawing _kolams_, known as _alpana_ or _[rangoli](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rangoli)_ in Bengal.[\[558\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TOI-Kolam-2-558) ### Government [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=42) The government used various methods to stop the protests, including [mass shooting](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_shooting) by [riot police](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riot_police),[\[469\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Stone_Pelting_Cops-469)[\[468\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Nadwa_video-468) [_lathi charge_](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baton_charge), [mass arrest](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_arrest), [Internet shutdown](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_shutdown), [curfew](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curfew), transport restrictions, [water cannon](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Water_cannon), and imposing ban on assembly ( [Section 144](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Section_144)).[\[675\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-gulfnews_23_Dec-675)[\[676\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-HuffPost_26_Dec_shot-676) ## Participants [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=43) The law was considered controversial since the time it was proposed, leading to protests from students, political organisations and citizen groups. On 4 December, the draft legislation was shared and the student organisation, [All Assam Students' Union](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_Assam_Students%27_Union) (AASU) objected to the proposal. AASU had participated in the [Assam Movement](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Movement) in the 1970s and 1980s against the illegal immigration of Bangladeshis.[\[677\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-MC_short_history-677) The protests started in Assam in early December. By 12 December, students in at least 50 colleges and universities nationwide had joined the protests.[\[678\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-678) The student protests subsequently grew and spread all over the country and several political and citizen groups joined it.[\[677\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-MC_short_history-677) The protests came into national and international prominence after the police crackdown following the violent crackdown of protests in Aligarh Muslim University[\[679\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-679)[\[680\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-680) and Jamia Millia Islamia.[\[681\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-681)[\[682\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-682) Student leaders from Jamia Millia Islamia Aysha Renna[\[683\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-683) and Ladeeda Farzana who were brutally attacked became the prominent faces of the movement.[\[684\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-684)[\[685\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-685)[\[686\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-686)[\[687\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-687)[\[688\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-688) ### Student organisations [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=44) #### Protesting [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=45) - [Naga Students' Federation](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naga_Students%27_Federation) - All Bodo Students Association - Wesean Student Federation[\[717\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-717) - [Twipra Students Federation](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twipra_Students_Federation)[\[716\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-HTNotNorthEast-716) - [All India Sikh Students Federation](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_India_Sikh_Students_Federation)[\[718\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-718) - [All Idu Mishmi Students Union](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_Idu_Mishmi_Students_Union)[\[719\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-719) - [All Tai Ahom Students’ Union](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_Tai_Ahom_Students_Union)[\[720\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-720) #### Pro-government [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=46) - [Akhil Bhartiya Vidyarthi Parishad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Akhil_Bhartiya_Vidyarthi_Parishad) (student wing of the [Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rashtriya_Swayamsevak_Sangh))[\[705\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ABVP2-705) - [Bharatiya Janata Yuva Morcha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Yuva_Morcha) (student wing of the [Bharatiya Janata Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party)) ## Casualties [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=47) As of 4 January, 21 people were killed by police firing guns during the CAA protests in Uttar Pradesh,[\[529\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_4_Jan_bullet-529)[\[68\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-India_Today_deaths-68)[\[182\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_16_Killed-182) 3 killed in Karnataka[\[182\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_16_Killed-182) and 5 in Assam. Overall, 27 people were killed in the whole of India.[\[67\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-aljazeera_27_Dead-67)[\[721\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-The_Wire_25_dead-721) With 19 killed and 1,246 people arrested based on 372 FIRs lodged in the state, UP was the most affected state with the biggest police crackdown in India.[\[206\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CAA_Express_live_28_Dec-206) - **12 December** Names of those killed in anti-caa protests on a miniature India Gate artwork at Shaheen Bagh on 11 January 2020. - Dipanjal Das (23), Sam Stafford (17), Abdul Alim (23), Ishwar Nayak (25), Azizul Haque (45) and Dwijendra Panging (35) in [Assam](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam).[\[722\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-WireAssamKilled19-722) - **19 December** - Nausheen Bengre (23) and Jaleel Kudroli (49) in Mangalore, [Karnataka](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karnataka)[\[723\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ITMangaluruKilled19-723)[\[721\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-The_Wire_25_dead-721) - **20 December** - Mohammad Sageer (8), in Varanasi Uttar Pradesh, was killed in a stampede of people fleeing police [lathi charge](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lathi_charge) following CAA protests after Friday prayers.[\[721\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-The_Wire_25_dead-721)[\[724\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-724) - Mohammad Wakeel (25) in Uttar Pradesh. - Aftab Alam (22) and Mohammad Saif (25) in Kanpur, Uttar Pradesh[\[721\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-The_Wire_25_dead-721) - Asif (20), Arif (25), Zaheer (40), and Moshin (25) from Meerut, Uttar Pradesh[\[486\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_6_killed-486) - Nabi Jahan (24) in Firozabad, Uttar Pradesh[\[721\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-The_Wire_25_dead-721) - Faiz Khan (24) in Rampur, Uttar Pradesh[\[721\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-The_Wire_25_dead-721) - Anas (22) and Sulaiman (26) from Nehtaur area, [Bijnor](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bijnor), Uttar Pradesh[\[486\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_6_killed-486) - Noor-e-Alam in Muzaffarnagar, Uttar Pradesh[\[486\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_6_killed-486) - **21 December** - Mohammad Bilal (27) and Shehroz (22) in Uttar Pradesh.[\[725\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-21_Dec_Scroll-725) ## Impact [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=48) As the ongoing protest against the Citizenship Act turned violent, authorities of [Gauhati University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gauhati_University), [Dibrugarh University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dibrugarh_University) and [Cotton University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cotton_University) postponed all semester exams scheduled up-to 16 December 2019.[\[726\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-726) No play was possible on the fourth day of the [cricket](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cricket) match between [Assam](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_cricket_team) and [Services](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Services_cricket_team) in the [2019–20 Ranji Trophy](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019%E2%80%9320_Ranji_Trophy) because of the protests.[\[727\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-727) [BCCI](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Board_of_Cricket_Control_in_India) shifted two fixtures featuring three northeastern teams to other venues.[\[728\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-728) The protests also affected the football matches of [NorthEast United](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/NorthEast_United_FC), with their fixture against [Chennaiyin](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chennaiyin_FC) getting postponed.[\[729\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-729) The India-Japan summit in Guwahati, which was supposed to be attended by Japanese Prime Minister [Shinzo Abe](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shinz%C5%8D_Abe) was also cancelled.[\[730\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-730)[\[731\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-731) ### Economy [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=49) _[The Indian Express](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Indian_Express)_ reported that, during the second half of December, there had been a decline in the sales of cars, watches and other consumer goods, due to the ongoing protests.[\[732\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ET_Cars_13_Jan-732) ### Transport [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=50) Several trains and at least 700 flights were delayed and more than 20 cancelled as a result of the protests.[\[733\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-733)[\[174\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Flights-174) Train services were completely suspended in parts of Assam after two railway stations in the state were set on fire. It was reported that the [Indian Railways](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Railways) suffered losses worth [₹](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_rupee)90 [crore](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crore) (US$11 million) in property damage due to the protests, including losses worth over ₹72 crore (US$8.6 million) in West Bengal alone.[\[734\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-734) On 20 December, the [Kerala State Road Transport Corporation](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerala_State_Road_Transport_Corporation) suspended all bus services to Mangalore, while many [Karnataka State Road Transport Corporation](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karnataka_State_Road_Transport_Corporation) buses were blocked in Kerala.[\[735\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-735) On 19 and 20 December, several stations of the [Delhi Metro](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_Metro) were closed as a precautionary measure.[\[736\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-736)[\[737\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-737) On 19 December, the [Delhi-Gurgaon highway](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_Gurgaon_Expressway) was closed in view of the protests scheduled in Delhi.[\[738\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-738) ### Communication [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=51) The government imposed [internet shutdowns](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_outage) in the states of [Assam](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam) and [Tripura](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tripura), five districts in [West Bengal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Bengal), [Bhopal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhopal), [Dakshina Kannada](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dakshina_Kannada) and parts of Delhi.[\[739\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-739)[\[14\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-The_Hindu-14)[\[740\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-740)[\[483\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto-483) Mobile internet and SMS services were suspended in several places in [Uttar Pradesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh) such as [Lucknow](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucknow), [Ghaziabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ghaziabad), [Bareilly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bareilly), [Meerut](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meerut) and [Prayagraj](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prayagraj).[\[741\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-741)[\[742\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-742) ### Tourism [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=52) Canada, France, Israel, Russia, Singapore, [Taiwan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taiwan), the U.S. and the UK have issued travel advisories for nationals travelling to northeast India.[\[743\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto9-743)[\[744\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto8-744)[\[745\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-tourism-745) The protests reportedly resulted in a 60% decline in tourists visiting the [Taj Mahal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taj_Mahal) in [Agra](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agra) for the month of December. The number of visitors went down by at least 90% in the state of Assam, according to the head of [Assam Tourism Development Corporation](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Tourism_Development_Corporation).[\[745\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-tourism-745) ## Reactions [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=53) ### Domestic [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=54) #### Return of Awards and Honours [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=55) - [Mujtaba Hussain](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mujtaba_Hussain) returned his [Padma Shri](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Padma_Shri) and claimed Indian democracy has reduced to "a joke".[\[746\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-746)[\[747\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-747) - The crews of the [Malayalam film](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malayalam_film) _[Sudani from Nigeria](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sudani_from_Nigeria),_ which had won a [national award for the best Malayalam film](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Film_Award_for_Best_Feature_Film_in_Malayalam) in the 66th [National Film Awards](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Film_Awards) decided to boycott the awards ceremony over the protests.[\[748\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-748)[\[749\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-749) - [Shirin Dalvi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shirin_Dalvi) decided to return his [Maharashtra Rajya Sahitya Akademi Award](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sahitya_Akademi_Award).[\[750\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-return-750)[\[751\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-return2-751) - [Jahnu Barua](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jahnu_Barua) withdrew his film _[Bhoga Khirikee](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhoga_Khirikee)_ from the Assam State Film Awards.[\[752\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-752)[\[753\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-753) ### International [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=56) - **Afghanistan**: Former Afghanistan President [Hamid Karzai](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamid_Karzai) urged Government of India to treat all minorities equally. In an interview to _[The Hindu](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Hindu)_, he said, "We don't have persecuted minorities in Afghanistan." Mentioning about the [Afghanistan conflict](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Afghanistan_conflict_(1978%E2%80%93present)), he said, "The whole country is persecuted. We have been in war and conflict for a long time. All religions in Afghanistan, Muslims and Hindus and Sikhs, which are our three main religions, have suffered."[\[754\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-754) - **Bangladesh**: In an interview to _[Gulf News](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gulf_News)_ Bangladesh Prime Minister [Sheikh Hasina](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sheikh_Hasina) said, "Within India, people are facing many problems" and expressed her concerns saying, "We don't understand why (the Indian government) did it. It was not necessary". Though she maintained her stance that the CAA and NRC are internal matters of India. But Hasina's government had previously said that minority communities did not leave Bangladesh because of persecution. She also said that Prime Minister Modi assured her of no reverse migration from India.[\[755\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-755) - **China**: _[People's Daily](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/People%27s_Daily)_, an official newspaper of [Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Committee_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party), justified internet restrictions citing India's internet shutdowns. The newspaper said that India did not hesitate to shut down the internet in its two states when there was a significant threat to its national security; according to an article in _[The Times of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Times_of_India)_, activists described the justification as setting a dangerous precedent for internet freedom.[\[756\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-756)[\[757\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-757) - **Hungary**: The [Fidesz](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fidesz) Hungarian government in Hungary has expressed support for India on [Kashmir](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Revocation_of_the_special_status_of_Jammu_and_Kashmir) and the Citizenship Amendment Act protests.[\[758\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-758) - **Kuwait**: In a statement issued during [National Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Assembly_(Kuwait)) session in Kuwait group of lawmakers expressed their concern regarding "abusive legislative and repressive security measures" taken by the Government of India.[\[759\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-759) - **Malaysia**: Malaysian Prime Minister [Mahathir Mohamad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahathir_Mohamad) said "Already people are dying because of this law, so why is there a necessity to do this thing?".[\[760\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-760) In response, the Government of India summoned the Chargé d'Affaires of the Malaysian Embassy over the matter.[\[761\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-761) - **Pakistan**: The Prime Minister of Pakistan, [Imran Khan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imran_Khan) criticised the CAA by claiming that "the present Government. of India has been exposed of its fascist agenda as minorities have come out to protest against the CAA". He also expressed his concern that, such policies by the government. may create a major refugee crisis in the sub-continent.[\[762\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-762)[\[763\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-763) - **United States**: [US Congress](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Congress) think tank [Congressional Research Service](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Congressional_Research_Service) expressed concerns that the CAA along with the NRC may affect the status of the Indian Muslim community.[\[764\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-764) #### Organisation [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=57) - **European Union**: EU resolution states that CAA marks 'a dangerous shift ' in the way citizenship will be determined in India and is set to create the 'largest statelessness crisis in the world'.[\[765\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-765) - **Organisation of Islamic Cooperation**: [OIC](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation) expressed their concern about present situation of CAA-NRC and urged the Government of India to ensure the safety of the Muslim minority and to follow obligation of [Charter of the United Nations](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charter_of_the_United_Nations).[\[766\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-766) - **United Nations**: [Secretary-General of the United Nations](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secretary-General_of_the_United_Nations), [António Guterres](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ant%C3%B3nio_Guterres) condemned the "violence and alleged use of excessive force by security forces" and urged the Government of India to respect the freedom of expression and opinion and [freedom of peaceful assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freedom_of_assembly).[\[767\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-767) ### Human rights organisations [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=58) - [United Nations Commission on Human Rights](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations_Commission_on_Human_Rights) (UNCHR): [Stéphane Dujarric](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/St%C3%A9phane_Dujarric), the spokesperson for the [U.N. High Commissioner for Human Rights](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Office_of_the_United_Nations_High_Commissioner_for_Human_Rights) (OHCHR) had said that it is ‘concerned’ that the CAA is ‘fundamentally discriminatory in nature’.[\[768\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-768) In a press briefing OHCHR said that CAA appears to "undermine the commitment to equality before the law enshrined in India's constitution and India's obligations under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the Convention for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination", which prohibit discrimination based on racial, ethnic or religious grounds. It also said that "all migrants, regardless of their migration status, are entitled to respect, protection and fulfilment of their human rights."[\[769\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-769) - [Human Rights Watch](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch) (HRW): South Asia Director for HRW, Meenakshi Ganguly said that the "government failed to grasp the extent of public opposition over the erosion of basic rights evident in these protests". She urged that the government must establish an independent investigation into allegations of "excessive force, brutality, and vandalism" by police. Its "strongest response to the protests would be to repeal" the Act and "withdraw its plan for citizenship verification that threatens marginalized communities", the organisation said.[\[770\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-770) According to an 82-page report published on 9 April 2020, by [Human Rights Watch](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch), "‘Shoot the Traitors’: Discrimination Against Muslims Under India's New Citizenship Policy," the police forces and other law enforcement officials perpetually failed in intervening during clashes between the supporters of the [BJP](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/BJP) government and those protesting against the new citizenship policies, in which the latter became a victim of repeated attacks.[\[771\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-771) - [Amnesty International](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amnesty_International): Avinash Kumar, Executive Director of Amnesty India said "The CAA is a bigoted law that legitimises discrimination on the basis of religion." He also said that people should have the right to protest peacefully and should have right to freedom of peaceful assembly which facilitate freedom of expression and allows public debate. However, the Central Government and other state governments "rather than respecting, protecting and promoting this right, are clamping down on protestors by using repressive laws".[\[772\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-772) Amnesty has also informed the US lawmakers that the CAA stands in "clear violation" of the constitution of India and international human rights law and "legitimises discrimination" on the basis of religion.[\[773\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-773) ## Pro-CAA demonstrations [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=59) Rallies and demonstrations in support of Citizenship Amendment Bill were held in New Delhi,[\[774\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-774)[\[775\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-775) Mumbai,[\[776\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-776) Nagpur,[\[777\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-777) Bangalore,[\[778\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-778) Dehradun[\[779\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-779) and many other places.[\[780\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ddnews_24_Dec-780) A rally in Kolkata was headed by [Jagat Prakash Nadda](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jagat_Prakash_Nadda), working national president of BJP, and was attended by persecuted Hindu refugees from Pakistan and Bangladesh.[\[781\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-781)[\[782\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-782) Protests against CAA were condemned in these rallies and hailed Prime Minister [Narendra Modi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Narendra_Modi) for taking a decision on CAA.[\[783\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-783)[\[784\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-784) Nine [Jain](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jainism) organisations came out in support of CAA on 20 December 2019 and thanked a BJP politician and BJP for the Amendment.[\[702\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-HTChandigarh-702) Over 1,000 academicians released statements in support of CAA.[\[785\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-785) Signatories included [Swapan Dasgupta](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swapan_Dasgupta), [Shishir Bajoria](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shishir_Bajoria), journalist [Kanchan Gupta](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kanchan_Gupta) and [JNU](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru_University) faculty and administration including professor [Ainul Hasan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amin_ul-Hasanat), JNU dean of students Umesh Ashok Kadam and JNU registrar Pramod Kumar.[\[786\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-786) The President of [Delhi University Students' Union](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_University_Students%27_Union) released a statement in support of the CAA which was condemned by partisan student unions of colleges under Delhi University. A pro-CAA rally named _Jana Jagarana Rally_, was organised at [Tirupati](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tirupati) and attended by BJP national vice-president and former Madhya Pradesh Chief Minister [Shivraj Singh Chouhan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shivraj_Singh_Chouhan) and mostly BJP workers. The participants raised slogans in support of CAA and carried placards with slogans such as _‘We support CAA’_, _‘India supports CAA’_, _‘CAA a punishment to intruders and traitors’_ and _‘CAA protects refugees’_. The participants also carried a 500-metre-long [Indian national flag](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_national_flag).[\[787\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-787) ### Assam [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=60) A rally was organised by BJP to support the Citizenship Amendment Act in Assam's [Morigaon](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morigaon)[\[788\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-788) on 27 December in which over 50,000 civilians, including BJP workers, [Asom Gana Parishad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asom_Gana_Parishad) and [Bodoland People's Front](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bodoland_People%27s_Front) leaders took part.[\[789\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-789) The 4-km long rally was led by Assam [Chief Minister](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_Minister) of Assam [Sarbananda Sonowal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarbananda_Sonowal) and state Finance Minister [Himanta Biswa Sarma](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Himanta_Biswa_Sarma).[\[790\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-790) ### West Bengal [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=61) Thousands of BJP workers took out a massive rally named _Abhinandan Yatra_ or _Thanks-giving rally_ in North Kolkata in support of CAA on 30 December.[\[791\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto10-791)[\[792\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-792) It was led by the party's Working President [J P Nadda](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/J_P_Nadda) to thank Prime Minister [Narendra Modi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Narendra_Modi) for enacting the Citizenship Amendment Act.[\[793\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-793)[\[791\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto10-791) ### Gujarat [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=62) On 24 December, a large gathering was organised at [Sabarmati Ashram](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sabarmati_Ashram), [Ahmedabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ahmedabad).[\[794\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-794) [Vijay Rupani](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vijay_Rupani), Chief Minister of Gujarat was present at the event, said that Gujarat will definitely implement CAA.[\[795\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-795)[\[796\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-796) He also stated that Muslims have 150 countries to go while Hindus have only one.[\[797\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-797)[\[798\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-LawSupport-798) BJP leaders and ministers took parts in the different rallies organised across all 33 districts of Gujarat.[\[799\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto6-799)[\[800\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-800)[\[801\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-801) ### Maharashtra [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=63) Maharashtra witnessed pro-CAA demonstrations in cities including Nagpur, Mumbai, [Yavatmal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yavatmal), [Wardha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wardha) and Pune.[\[802\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-802) On 23 December 2019, RSS linked organisations carried out rally in Nagpur which was attended by [Nitin Gadkari](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nitin_Gadkari) and [Devendra Fadnavis](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Devendra_Fadnavis) along with more than 25,000 people.[\[803\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-803)[\[804\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-804) [Devendra Fadnavis](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Devendra_Fadnavis), former chief minister of Maharashtra, targeted [Shiv Sena](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shiv_Sena) at the event organised by BJP's Samvidhan Sanman Manch and also organised pro-CAA rally in [Mumbai](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mumbai).[\[805\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-805) ### Phone call campaign [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=64) Several BJP leaders including Home Minister Amit Shah had publicised a phone number, asking people to call the number as a way to show their support for the CAA. Many accounts on social media were seen sharing the same number and asking people to call, intending to inflate the number of supporters of CAA.[\[806\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-HuffPost_4_Jan-806) The number was also shared on bogus posts offering free six-month subscriptions to the streaming site [Netflix](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netflix) for free. Netflix called the offer as fake.[\[807\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Netflix_4_Jan-807) ### Fake videos [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=65) A video of _[Naga Sadhus](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naga_Sadhu)_ celebrating at [Kumbh Mela](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kumbh_Mela) at [Allahabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allahabad) in March 2019 was shared and made [viral](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viral_video) on social media,[\[808\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-808) falsely claiming that this was the video of Hindus in the rally supporting CAA.[\[809\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-DB_8_Jan_fake_video-809)[\[810\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-810) ### Overseas [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=66) Members of the Indian-American community held a pro-CAA rally in front of the Indian Consulate in Houston on 20 December 2019.[\[811\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-811) They also held other rallies at [Victor Steinbrueck Park](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victor_Steinbrueck_Park), [Seattle](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle) and [Texas State Capitol](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Texas_State_Capitol) building in [Austin](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austin,_Texas) on 22 December 2019. Rallies were also held at Ted Kaltenbach Park, [Dublin](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dublin,_California), [Ohio](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ohio) and at Nash Square Park, [Raleigh, North Carolina](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raleigh,_North_Carolina).[\[812\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-812) ## Petitions in Supreme Court [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=67) On 14 January, the [Kerala government](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerala_government) approached Supreme Court to challenge the CAA under section 131 of the constitution that provides Supreme Court the power to decide the disputes between the states and the Government of India.[\[257\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Kerala_CAA_14_Jan-257)[\[258\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-14_Jan-258) The Kerala government in its petition called the act "a violation of India's secular constitution" and accused the Indian government of dividing the country among religious lines.[\[577\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-aljazeera_14_Jan-577) The Supreme Court had scheduled the hearing of CAA related petitions on 22 January. The students' association have called a complete shutdown of the colleges and university in the north-east, on 22 January, asking the court to declare CAA unconstitutional.[\[283\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_NE_strike_21_Jan-283) On 22 January 144 CAA related petitions scheduled for hearing in the Supreme Court of India were brought up. The [Chief Justice of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_India) (CJI) [Sharad A. Bobde](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sharad_A._Bobde) had led the three judge bench in hearing the petitions.[\[289\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-144_petitions_21_Jan-289) The court gave notice to the government on the petitions and allowed one month time to respond in the next hearing in February.[\[290\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-SC_refuses_22_Jan-290) K.V. Vishwanathan, a senior advocate addressed the court, stating "The most immediate concern now is the sweeping powers given to [executive authorities](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Executive_(government)) to brand people as 'doubtful citizens'. Once this is done, there are no guidelines to help these people. This is sinister. It will lead to [gerrymandering](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerrymandering) of electoral rolls. The concern is spread across both the majority Hindus and the minorities as well. You have to address this fear... Otherwise fear and insecurity will pervade the country."[\[290\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-SC_refuses_22_Jan-290) Reacting to the concerns the CJI stated that the laws like the CAA are not irreversible, and the court will hear the interim prayer for a stay on CAA at a future date in February.[\[290\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-SC_refuses_22_Jan-290) On 3 March, the [Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Office_of_the_United_Nations_High_Commissioner_for_Human_Rights) (OHCHR), filed an application in the Supreme Court and asked to be made a party in the case citing "the exclusions of persons... on the basis of their religion". The OHCHR Commissioner, [Michelle Bachelet](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michelle_Bachelet) said that the "differentiations" drawn by the Act are not "sufficiently objective and reasonable". However, the [Ministry of External Affairs](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ministry_of_External_Affairs_(India)) reacted to the move and said that the CAA is an "internal matter" of India and "no foreign party had any locus standi on issues pertaining to India's sovereignty".[\[813\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-813)[\[348\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-UN_moves_to_SC-348) ## See also [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=68) - full_text: Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) | Washington, D.C. Significant Cyber Incidents Since 2006 This timeline lists significant cyber incidents since 2006. We focus on state actions, espionage, and cyberattacks where losses are more than a million dollars. This is a living document. When we learn of a cyber incident, we add it to the chronological order. If you think we’ve missed something, please send an email to strategictech@csis.org. October 2025: The ransomware group Medusa claimed responsibility for a data breach involving SimonMed Imaging, during which hackers exfiltrated data belonging to approximately 1.2 million patients. The attackers reportedly demanded $1 million to delete the stolen files, and SimonMed has brought in cybersecurity experts to investigate. October 2025: Hackers uploaded 23 million customer records belonging to several companies, including Vietnam Airlines, on data-trading forums. Vietnam Airlines confirmed this data-breach incident, which exposed customers’ personal information linked to its technology partner’s online customer service platform. October 2025: Canadian Centre for Cyber Security warned that hacktivist groups have exploited industrial control systems at critical infrastructure sites. Attackers were observed leveraging weak security configurations, default credentials, and unpatched internet-facing PLCs and HMIs. October 2025: North Korean Lazarus APT group targeted three European defense sector companies to steal sensitive information on drone components and manufacturing processes. The attackers used a social engineering campaign, sending fake job offers with a remote access trojan. The targeted companies supply military equipment to Ukraine and possess specialized knowledge on advanced single-rotor drones that North Korea is actively developing. October 2025: Russian cybercrime group Lynx breached Dodd Group, a UK Ministry of Defence contractor, stealing approximately 4TB of data, including sensitive files on eight RAF and Royal Navy bases. The attackers deployed ransomware and exfiltrated visitor logs, staff details, security guidance, and construction records and began leaking roughly 1,000 documents. The UK MoD has launched an investigation into this breach. September 2025: A ransomware gang calling itself Radiant breached Kido International, a childcare provider operating 18 London nurseries, and exfiltrated photographs and personal data of more than 8,000 children. The attackers used phishing emails to obtain remote-desktop access and deploy encryption tools. The group later claimed to delete the data after public backlash. September 2025: A ransomware attack on Collins Aerospace’s vMUSE airport operations platform disrupted check-in and boarding systems at Heathrow, Brussels, and Berlin airports. The malware encrypted backend servers, forcing airlines to revert to manual check-in and causing hundreds of flight delays. European aviation authorities have not attributed the incident. Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) | Washington, D.C. September 2025: Hackers infiltrated servers belonging to luxury conglomerate Kering, stealing personal data from clients of Gucci, Balenciaga, and Alexander McQueen. The attackers used credential-stuffing tools and web-exfiltration scripts. The criminal group ShinyHunters claimed responsibility, though Kering did not confirm their involvement. September 2025: Threat actors exploited stolen OAuth 2.0 refresh tokens from Salesloft and Drift integrations to exfiltrate Salesforce data from hundreds of corporate environments worldwide. The financially motivated campaign affected firms across the finance, technology, and logistics sectors, with some estimates suggesting over a billion records accessed. September 2025: Cybercriminals attacked Jaguar Land Rover’s IT network with ransomware that disrupted manufacturing and retail operations across multiple UK plants. The attack is estimated to cost £1.9B and be the most economically damaging cyber event in UK history. A group calling itself Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters claimed responsibility, though UK authorities have not confirmed attribution. August 2025: The U.S., Five Eyes partners, and other allies accused three Chinese firms of aiding Beijing’s intelligence services in cyber espionage.
